BONDS BEING PUSHED ACROSS TABLES AND SIGNED AT BANK OF

DODD/FRANK BANKING REFORM BEING SIGNED, 3. BANKERS BEING

OVER BLACK WE SEE THE QUOTE
FORECLOSED AND FOR SALE SIGNS ON ALL THEM, (STOCK FOOTAGE)
QUICK FLASH TO THE CELL PHONE ON THE GROUND. 32
OVER DRINKS, LUNCH, BLACKJACK TABLE, POOL SIDE.
AMERICA, BEAR STEARNS, MORGAN STANLEY, CREDIT SUISSE ETC.
CHARLIE, JAMIE AND BEN MEETING DIFFERENT BANKS

dialogues.speaker: OPEN ON
dialogues.text: A bunch of FAT BOND TRADERS eat deli sandwiches and smoke cigarettes on the Solomon Brothers Bond Trading floor. It not exactly Michael Douglas in Wall Street. The voice that walks us through this is smart, too the po and slick. We’ll meet him later.

dialogues.speaker: MODERN TRADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the late seventies banking was not a job you went into to make large sums of money. It was a good stable profession like selling insurance or accounting. And if banking was boring then the bond department at a bank was downright comatose. We all know about bonds, give em to your nephew when he turns 16 and then we he’s thirty he makes a hundred dollars. Yawn. Bonds were for losers. That is, until Lewis Ranieri came on the scene at Solomon Brothers... MUSIC: Some great 70’s ballad like KISS YOU ALL OVER by E We see an even schlubbier version of the other Bond Trade emerge. His suit is rumpled, he has a mustard stain on hi shirt from a soft pretzel he’s eating and he is easily seventy pounds over weight. This is LEWIS RENIERI. And th his world is obscure, he is the shit. Our NARRATOR the MODERN TRADER passes through the scene f second, dressed in modern clothes... Lewis greets his Bond Department with obscenities barked through his patchy beard and glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MODERN TRADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You see Lewis didn’t know it yet, but he had already changed banking forever. He had just one simple idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis and HIS TEAM are doing a presentation to a bunch of STATE PENSION FUND MANAGERS with an old fashioned OVER HE PROJECTOR.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 3.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS RANIERI
dialogues.text: ...The mortgage backed security. Or the private label M.B.S.

dialogues.speaker: FUND MANAGER
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: BOND TRADER
dialogues.text: I hope you don’t say that when you look at your wife’s pussy! They all HOWL except the fund manager who looks shocked b then finally laughs to fit in.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS RANIERI
dialogues.text: Here's how it works. You’ve got your average person’s mortgage. Fixed rate, 30 years... We see A HOUSE on the over head projector. LEWIS RANIERI (CONT’D) Boring, safe, small pay off... Right? But when you have thousands of them all bundled together... We see an illustration of many homes. The next illustrati shows them all “bundled” together with a bow. LEWIS RANIERI (CONT’D) Suddenly the yield goes up and the risk is still low cause it’s a mortgage and who the hell doesn’t pay their mortgage?

dialogues.speaker: BOND TRADER
dialogues.text: Dickheads and junkies.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS RANIERI
dialogues.text: And because the risk is hedged these bonds allow for people with not so perfect credit to get homes. So you’re making money and you’re doing a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: BOND TRADER
dialogues.text: Lewie is a fucking genius.

dialogues.speaker: FUND MANAGER
dialogues.text: Uhm, what exactly is the credit rating on this bond? All my pension fund cares about is triple A rated risk.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 4.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS RANIERI
dialogues.text: Risk? What risk? The only risk is that you get paid back too soon! Plus each of these mortgages is guaranteed by the U.S. Government. This bond gentlemen, is AAA rated.

dialogues.speaker: FUND MANAGER
dialogues.text: This is exactly what the Michigan State pension fund has been looking for. I’1l buy 20 million...

dialogues.speaker: BOND TRADER
dialogues.text: Come on live a little!

dialogues.speaker: FUND MANAGER
dialogues.text: Twenty five million.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS RANIERI
dialogues.text: Let’s break out the paper work! MUSIC: Something like BOOGIE OOGIE OOGIE by A TASTE OF HO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bond Traders are partying at a strip club throwing dollars everywhere and boozing. It disgusting and fun as and none of these guys will live past 60.

dialogues.speaker: MODERN TRADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Lewis and his band of foul mouthed bond traders took a sleepy department and made it the most profitable on Wall Street. Pretty soon stocks and savings were almost inconsequential to the big banks. They were doing 50, 100, 200 billion in mortgage bonds and dozens of other securities a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME LAPSE: New impressive BANKING BUILDINGS SPRING UP an dot the Manhattan skyline. Chase, B of A, Morgan Stanley, Lehman Brothers etc.

dialogues.speaker: MODERN TRADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And America barely noticed as it’s number one industry became boring old banking. Then one day... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MODERN TRADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: almost thirty years later... in 2008... It all came crashing down.

dialogues.speaker: WINS ANCR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Wall Street has suffered one of it’s worst days in history as Lehman Brothers has declared bankruptcy.

dialogues.speaker: WINS ANCR, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: This follows the demise of Bear Stearns and a plummeting Dow Jones, down four thousand since January.

dialogues.speaker: MODERN TRADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the end Lewis Ranieri’s Mortgage Backed Security mutated into a monstrosity that collapsed the whole world economy. And none of the experts or leaders or talking heads had a clue it was coming. I’m guessing most of you still don’t really know what happened. Yeah, you got a sound bite you repeat so you don’t sound dumb but come on... WE FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: MODERN TRADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But there were some who saw it coming... While the whole world was having a big ol’ party, a few outsiders and weirdos saw what no one else could. Not me, I’m not a weirdo. I’m pretty cool. We’1l meet later. These outsiders saw the giant lie at the heart of the economy. And they saw it by doing something the rest of the suckers never thought to do: they looked.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 6.

dialogues.speaker: GRAPHIC
dialogues.text: A MIDDLE SCHOOL football game is in progress. MICHAEL BUR age 11 catches a ball and starts running. He’s pretty goo His parents and coaches cheer him on. Cute 8th GRADE CHEERLEADERS wave their pom poms.

dialogues.speaker: PARENTS /COACH
dialogues.text: Thatta way Michael! Go! Go! He is TACKLED by a few players and as Michael gets up we an OPPOSING PLAYER scream.

dialogues.speaker: OPPOSING PLAYER
dialogues.text: Ewwww! Look! CU_of a GLASS EYE on the field. Michael covers his eye wi his hand.

dialogues.speaker: OPPOSING PLAYERS
dialogues.text: Gross! His eye fell out! He’s a freak! etc. Michael picks the eye up and walks back to the side lines still covering his one eye. Another player runs into repl him.

dialogues.speaker: PA ANCR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Replacing Michael Burry at tight end, number 88, Scott Proffer! A CUTE CHEERLEADER looks at Michael with her nose scrunch up and then looks away. His MOM and DAD meet him.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: It’s okay Michael. Let’s just wash it off and put it back in.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: You were playing so well son. I heard the coach compliment you.

dialogues.speaker: YR OLD MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Can we just go home? He walks away.  10 11 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see from under the water ADULT MICHAEL BURRY swimming laps. His strokes are clean and strong. Michael Burry gets out of the pool. He towels off and wal immediately to the lockers.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve always been more comfortable alone. I believe it’s because of my glass eye. I lost the eye froma childhood illness. It separates me from people. Most social interactions are awkward. For me, for the person. Even when I try to compliment someone it comes out wrong... The compliment, not the eye. (quarter beat) That wasn’t a joke. I’m just being clear.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The other night there was a party with some old college associates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a party going on with upper class professionals drinking white wine and Heinekens. Michael stands alone between two groups of professionals talking.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: We bought the house two years ago for 650 and we just sold it for 950. We put 30 thousand into it tops...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH to Michael starting his car, a Honda, and leaving.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After ten minutes I left and went home and researched state by state mortgage fraud rates until three in the morning.  12 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 8. INT. MICHAEL BURRY’S FUND OFFICE - DAY 12 Michael is seated behind his desk in a t-shirt and shorts

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Did you know they’re going up? Highest fraud rates since the 1930's. We reveal he is talking to a YOUNG EAGER ANALYST in his office at the center of SCION CAPITAL, Michael Burry’s fu Michael’s office is at the front enclosed in glass. There 20 ANALYSTS working at desks in the main room outside the glass. A big white board shows the quarterly profits from Scion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: No. I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I’m going on and on. My wife says I need to share more.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH 2005
dialogues.text: 3 years 6 months until the crash

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: That seems healthy.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I like your hair. Did you cut it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: What? No. I uh, paid someone.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: So, do I get the job? I really think I could help your fund.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: What? Oh sure. Right. Yes...um  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 9.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: David. (onward) Great! I guess I’ll find a desk. Is there anything you want me to work on for starters?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Yes... Another long beat. Michael thinks. This beat keeps going. Finally the Young Analyst starts to speak just as Michael does. MICHAEL BURRY (CONT’D) YOUNG ANALYST Did you find it strange- You can let me know later- I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Did you find it odd that when the tech bubble burst in 2001 the housing market in San Jose, the tech center of the world, went up?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: Huh. I guess. I mean, no. It’s housing. It’s always AAA rated, low risk.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Yes.... That’s the idea... (he knows what he needs now) I need you to get me the top 20 selling mortgage bonds.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: So you want to know what the top 20 selling mortgage bonds are?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: No. I want to know what mortgages are in each one.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: Wait, aren’t those bonds made up of thousands and thousands of mortgages?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Yes. The Analyst waits for Burry to complete the thought but h doesn’t.  13 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 10.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: Right away Dr. Burry. Finally he leaves. Burry sits down at his desk and PUTS E BUDS IN while Googling “SEC mortgage brokerage firm violations” He gets no hits. MUSIC: Some hard-core heavy metal like BLOOD THUNDER by

dialogues.speaker: MASTADON
dialogues.text: An Asian American ASSISTANT walks by Burry’s office windo and LOOKS AT CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN AMERICAN ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: I was Michael’s actual assistant for years. I know what you’re thinking, a hedge fund manager with a glass eye who unwinds by listening to thrash metal, come on. But he really did do that. INT. SCION CAPITAL - MICHAEL BURRY’S OFFICE - NEXT DAY 13 CU of a COMPUTER SCREEN showing THOUSANDS OF COMPLICATED LINES OF MORTGAGES from a MORTGAGE BACKED SECURITY. The l are almost indecipherable but we see Michael Burry is rea them intently like it’s a page turning mystery novel.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (his internal thought process) 30 days late... Rate adjusts in one year... Foreclosed... Paid on time... rate adjusts in one year... Investment grade mortgage bonds full of high risk interest only adjustable rate mortgages... Do people really understand how an adjustable rate mortgage works?... Most of these are no money down loans... 105 LTV... 540 Fico score?... Why are the mortgage companies giving these people mortgages...? Outside Burry’s office we see the Analyst he just hired D at his desk talking to another ANALYST #2

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: What’s he doing? He hasn’t moved all day.  14 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 ll.

dialogues.speaker: ANALYST
dialogues.text: He does this every few days. He hasn’t spoken to me since he hired me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: 90 days late... 30 days late... These bonds are one of the banks’ biggest revenue sources... They need more mortgages to fill them... That’s why it’s all adjustable rate high risk... They’re giving mortgages to people who can’t afford mortgages in order to fill these bonds, in order to earn fees... As he continues to read we TIME LAPSE and see the employe start to leave at the end of day. Eventually THE MAIN ANALYST’S OFFICE IS EMPTY and THE SUN IS COMING UP OUTSID

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These mortgage bonds might fail... No one thinks they can fail, but all that subprime credit risk is real, no matter how they slice and dice it... 30 days late, rate will adjust next year... 60 days late... These bonds will fail... INT. MICHAEL’S OFFICE - THE NEXT AFTERNOON 14 Michael is on the phone. He clearly hasn’t slept and his clothes are rumpled. There are water bottles everywhere. Michael brushes his teeth over a garbage can with water.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Lawrence. I found something really interesting.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Great Michael. Whenever you find something interesting we all tend to make money. What stock are you valuing?  15 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 12.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: No stocks. I want to short the housing market. INT. METRO CAPITAL - LAWRENCE FIELDS’S OFFICE - SAME TIME LAWRENCE FIELDS’S office is the opposite of Michael’s. It lavish with Manhattan views as is he.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Haha! Really? But the housing market is rock solid. Greenspan just said bubbles are regional, defaults are rare. FIELDS motions to his assistant through the open door. LAWRENCE FIELDS (CONT’D) Tell them I’1l be there ina minute...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Greenspan’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: I don’t think you mean to do it but sometimes you sound very dismissive and superior Michael. Alan Greenspan is the greatest Fed Chairman in history.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: It’s a fact. Greenspan’s wrong. He’s too focused on being right to realize he’s wrong. I don’t know how else you want me to say it. Burry spits out his coffee gargle into the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Look, Metro Capital backed you four years ago when you were a doctor with a dinky web page and some inheritance money. And we've all done very well. Why don’t you just stick with stocks?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I look for value whereever it can be found. And the fact is: mortgage backed securities are filled with extremely risky subprime adjustable rate loans. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 The scene BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 13.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Once the majority of adjustable rates kick in 07’ they will begin to fail and when they fail above 15% the whole bond is worthless. freezes.

dialogues.speaker: MODERN TRADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mortgage backed securities, subprime loans, tranches... Pretty confusing right? Does it make you feel bored? Or stupid? Well, it’s supposed to. Wall Street loves to use confusing terms to make you think only they can do what they do. Or even better, for you to leave them the fuck alone. So here’s Scarlett Johansson under a water falls to explain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCARLETT JOHANSSON in a white T shirt and cut off jeans l the waterfall run over her while explaining mortgage back securities.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT JOHANSSON
dialogues.text: Basically Lewis Ranieri’s Mortgage bonds were amazingly profitable for the big banks. They made billions and billions off of their 2% fee on each of these bonds they sold. But then they started running out of mortgages to put in them. After all, there’s only so many homes and so many people with good enough jobs to buy them. So the banks starting doing something different. Instead of creating mortgage bonds that were guaranteed by the US government, they started creating their own private mortgage bonds. No government, no pesky standards like good credit or minimum income. And then the big banks were able to fill the bonds with riskier and riskier mortgages and keep the profit machine churning. By the way, the risky mortgages are called “subprime.” Anytime you hear subprime, think shit. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 13a.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT JOHANSSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Michael Burry found out these mortgage bonds that we supposedly 65% AAA were actually mostly full of shit, so now he’s going to “short” the bonds, which means to “bet against.” Got it? Good.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 14. 17 INT. MICHAEL BURRY’S FUND OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 17 Back to the scene.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: It’s only a matter of time before someone else sees this investment. We have to act now.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: And how do you know the bonds are built on subprime crap? Aren’t they filled with hundreds of pages of mortgages?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I read them.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: You read them? No one reads them. Only the lawyers who put them together read them.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I don’t think they even know what they made. The whole housing market is propped up on these bad loans. It’s a time bomb. And I want to short it.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Through what instrument Michael? There are no insurance contracts or options for mortgage bonds. The bonds are too stable. No one would buy them.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I’m going to get a bank to make me one. Then I’m going to buy a ton of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push in on Goldman Sachs. We see FINANCIAL NEWS on a monitor outside playing Jim Cramer’s Mad Money show.  19 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 15.

dialogues.speaker: JIM CRAMER
dialogues.text: Folks, this market ain't dropping! It’s like the running of the bulls in Pamplona. Either get out of the way or invest, invest, invest!

dialogues.speaker: THE FEMALE SALES REP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So, Dr. Burry, tell us about this trade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SALES REP (LUCY THALIA), an INDIAN NUMBERS GUY (DEEB WINSTON) all from Goldman Sachs sit across from Michael Burry. Michael looks very Men’s Warehouse in a blue blaze and slacks compared to the Goldman group who looks very G Prada suits.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I want to buy swaps on mortgage bonds. A credit default swap that pays off if the underlying bond fails.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REP
dialogues.text: You want to bet against the housing market?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DEEB WINSTON
dialogues.text: Why? These bonds only fail if millions of Americans don’t pay their mortgages. That’s never happened in history. If you'll excuse me Dr. Burry, it seems like a foolish investment.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Based on prevailing sentiment of the market, the big banks and popular culture, yes, it’s a foolish investment. But everyone's wrong. There’s a beat and then everyone laughs except Michael Bu who wasn’t kidding.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REP
dialogues.text: This is Wall Street, Dr. Burry. If you offer us free money, we are going to take it.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 16.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: My one concern is that when the bonds fail I want to be certain of payment in case of solvency issues with your bank. They are shocked.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REP
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Are you for real? You want to be against the housing market the most reliable sector of the American economy and you're worried we won’t pay you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s correct. The Goldman people whisper amongst themselves for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: DEEB WINSTON
dialogues.text: We could work out a pay as we go structure that would pay out if the bond’s value falls. But it would also apply to your payments if the value of the mortgage bond goes up. You’d have to pay us monthly premiums.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REP
dialogues.text: Is that acceptable Dr. Burry? Mike starts pulling thick DOCUMENTS out of his backpack. slides them across the table.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Yes it is. Here are prospectuses on 6 mortgage-backed securities I want to short. They scan them. They're diligent, they make us wait.

dialogues.speaker: DEEB WINSTON
dialogues.text: These should be fine.

dialogues.speaker: SALES REP
dialogues.text: We are prepared to sell you five million in credit default swaps on these mortgage bonds.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Can we do 100 million?  20 21 22 23 24 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael Burry leaves the conference room. AS HE CLOSES TH

dialogues.speaker: DOOR HE HEARS THE SALES REPS AND THE NUMBERS GUY LAUGHING
dialogues.text: CLAPPING. He hesitates, is he hurt? But then pushes on. MUSIC: Popular Hip Hop track like GOLD DIGGER by KANYE WE

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is there any way to buy 200 million?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is now across from SALES REPS from Deutsche Bank.

dialogues.speaker: DEUTSCHE SALES REP
dialogues.text: I, uh, I don’t see why not. But are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: DEUTSCHE SALES REP
dialogues.text: (waves off his colleague) Absolutely. Absolutely we can do that.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: That would be great. Here are the bonds I would like to bet against. He pushes another bundle of papers across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC CUTS OUT and we see Michael Burry through the f window eating alone at a chain restaurant. His phone buzz He answers. It’s a photo of his WIFE, and his 6 year old Nicholas. Under it, it reads “We miss you!”

dialogues.speaker: THE HIP HOP SONG KICKS BACK IN AS SOURCE. AN UPSCALE CLUB
dialogues.text: PACKED WITH BANKERS dancing and drinking. We focus in on the DEUTSCHE SALES REP AND COWORKERS WHO S BURRY THE SWAPS. They are clearly CELEBRATING HARD.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 18.

dialogues.speaker: TRADER
dialogues.text: Hey Randall, what’s with the Dom? Bonuses aren’t for three months.

dialogues.speaker: DEUTSCHE SALES REP
dialogues.text: We just sold 200 million today in credit swaps for mortgage bonds! Some fund manager from California! Fucking crazy right? It’s a whole new way to make money!

dialogues.speaker: TRADER
dialogues.text: I didn’t know there were swaps on mortgages!

dialogues.speaker: DEUTSCHE SALES REP
dialogues.text: There are now! We made one for him. He must have gone off his zoloft! More Dom is poured. A male and female sales rep make out. Trader steps over to another table and taps a guy on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TRADER
dialogues.text: Hey Jared! Did you hear about the deal Randall did with some fund manager? For the first time we see the Modern Trader, JARED VENNET 32. He’s smart, a bit slick with a slight Jheri curl and wears a sharp suit. HE’S OUR NARRATOR.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: Randall’s a foot soldier. It must be a shit deal.

dialogues.speaker: TRADER
dialogues.text: No, it’s for real. Jared LOOKS AT CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: I told you I’d come in later.

dialogues.speaker: TRADER
dialogues.text: Apparently this guy wanted 200 mill in credit default swaps on mortgage bonds! Randall made the sale. Can you believe it?!  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 19.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: Someone shorted 200 mill worth of mortgage bonds?

dialogues.speaker: TRADER
dialogues.text: That was just with Deutsche. Word is he hit half the town!

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: How much total? 25 INT. MICHAEL BURRY’S FUND OFFICE - DAY 25 Michael Burry is on the phone with Lawrence Fields.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: 1.3 billion.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: What?! That’s pretty much all of Scion’s liquidity! Michael this is highly distressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawrence Fields is in Florence with the David behind him. steps away to continue the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: It’s not all of our liquidity Lawrence. I’m not certain you understand this trade. This is a certainty.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Michael, I consider myself a mentor to you. But our company is not comfortable with this investment. Am I being clear?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I have full autonomy when it comes to investment strategy. You can read our agreement-

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Don’t throw our inception agreement in my face Michael. There was an underlying understanding that you wouldn’t act like a goddamn crazy man!  Half beat. BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 20.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: This isn’t crazy. It’s all very logical.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: So now we pay out premiums on these swaps against the housing market until the mortgages fail? In other words we lose millions until something that’s never happened before happens?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: That’s correct.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: And you have no doubts. You’re not nervous at all?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I have no doubts. But yes, I’m nervous. It’s a very large position for me to take.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: And will you please tell me what the difference between doubt and nervousness is?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: That is a very good question. And I’m sorry but I’1l have to get back to you on that. Have a nice vacation Lawrence. He hangs up. His computer and phone are dinging. QUICK CUTS OF EMAILS FROM MICHAEL BURRY’S INVESTORS: 1. “Have you lost your mind? I’m seriously worried about you.” 2. “What the hell is a credit default swap???” 3. “I am not comfortable trying to guess what the peak of 70 year housing spike is!” 4. “So you're telling me that rather than receiving profi on stocks I will now be paying premiums on these credit default swaps you bought? How is this in anyway good news And finally we push in on one last ominous email:  27 28 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 21. “BR LOT OF PEOPLE IN NEW YORK ARE TALKING ABOUT WITHDRAWI THEIR MONEY FROM YOUR_FUND.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU of a cell phone on the ground. We hear a voice.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Paul? Are you there Paul? Paul! We FLASH out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GROUP THERAPY SESSION
dialogues.text: A group of 7 PROFESSIONALS in suits sits in a circle with THERAPIST leading the group session. Businessman «+. I’m a nice guy all day long. Ask anyone. I’m a pleasure to work with. But the second my son screws up I’m yelling at him just like my Dad did to me- MARK BAUM, 40, moppish hair, rumpled suit, will always sa what he thinks, busts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry I’m late! No cabs! He sits down and starts right away. MARK BAUM (CONT’D) So, yeah. I met with this retail banker yesterday and I’m supposed to be getting him to invest in our fund but instead I start grilling him about over draught penalties and how his bank lets a customer write ten, twelve checks before they tell em they’re overdrawn. And this creep is making billions off of screwing over people this way-

dialogues.speaker: THERAPIST
dialogues.text: Mark-  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 22.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: And I'm getting madder and madder and I ask this guy how he sleeps at night knowing he’s ripping off working people and he just leaves. He doesn’t say a word. He just walks away from the lunch. So am I fucked up or is he? Beat as the room catches up.

dialogues.speaker: THERAPIST
dialogues.text: Mark, we've talked about this numerous times. You can’t come in late and hijack the entire session.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: I didn’t hijack the session. (to another businessman) Did I hijack the session.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: What’d you do?

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: I’m in commodities.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: Of course you are.

dialogues.speaker: THERAPIST
dialogues.text: Mark, I know you suffered a terrible loss... Maybe we can talk about that...?

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: I don’t talk about that. Hold on! Mark’s phone is buzzing. MARK BAUM (CONT’D) Oh shit. I have to take this. So sorry. He answers and walks out. MARK BAUM (CONT’D) (onto phone) I don’t care Porter. The guy’s whole business is built on ripping people off. How long can that last?  29

dialogues.speaker: BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 23.
dialogues.text: He leaves. The group is left stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see GIANT BILLBOARDS: for Movado watches, Mercedes SUV Designer jeans (with a topless woman with her back to us) We’re on the streets of Manhattan and Mark’s walking whil talking on his phone. MUSIC: Pop song like HIPS DON’T LIE by SHAKIRA plays on monitors in the window of an electronics store. January 2006 2 years 7 months until the collapse

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: I don’t want that kind of business... I’m sorry. Money’s not money... That’s bad money. Other than Goldman what company lasts ripping people off like that?

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mark Baum had built a career on never assuming anyone or any company was legit without proving it. When he was a kid he excelled at studying the Talmud in Yeshiva. That was great. But one day the Rabbi told his Mom why-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 YEAR OLD Mark Baum and his 8 YEAR OLD BROTHER PAUL run around with kids in the hallway of a Yashiva while his MO 35, talks to the RABBI, 52.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Paul is a fine boy. But his brother Mark... He is the best student of the Torah and the Talmud...

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Then what’s the problem Rabbi?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: It’s the reason.. He says he studies so hard because... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RABBI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: he is looking for inconsistencies in the word of God.  30 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 24. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: So has he found any?

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Later Baum started his own fund on Wall Street. He had an amazing nose for bullshit and wasn’t afraid to let everyone know when and where the bull had gone number 2. But then a tragedy happened to Mark that turned his world view dark and ready to believe the whole system was a lie.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: (sees he’s got another call) I gotta go, it’s Cynthia. I'll be in the office in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark’s wife, CYNTHIA (35). Their TWIN DAUGHTERS (10) are the floor on matching laptops while their SON (7) runs around.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Your therapist called me. You did it again.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: There were no cabs. What was I supposed to do? At least I went.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I worry about you Mark. You run around like you've got to right every wrong in the world. Everyone’s a creep or a crook.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: Fine. I’m a rude guy. And I’m pissed off. But it’s a shit storm out here sweetie. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 24a.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have no idea the crap people are pulling and the average person just walks around like they’re ina goddamn Enya video.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: Dreamy new-age song like ENYA’S ONLY TIME We see SLO MO people walking down the street. Some laughi Some stressed about work. Some eating hot dogs.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: They're all getting screwed... Credit cards, pay day lenders, car financing, fees, fees, and more fees. And what do they care about? The ball game or which actress went into rehab?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I think you should try medication.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Nooo. We agreed. If it interfered with work.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You hate Wall Street. Maybe it's time to quit. Mark is now trying to hail a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I love my job.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You hate your job.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I love my job!

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You're miserable! (gets quieter) Mark. I feel sad about what happened every day. I know you must feel the same... But you never show it.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Paul? Are you there Paul? Paul!  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 25A.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUILDING... AND STEP OFF.
dialogues.text: 33 34 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 26. WE CUT BACK TO MARK just as the man falls fully out of fr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence for a beat before Cynthia speaks.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I know how close you were to your brother... I keep hoping you’1ll talk about it. But you never do. And now you’re so distrustful of everything and everyone. You didn’t used to be this way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is quiet. He’s still unconsciously holding his arm u for a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Please don’t. I really can’t do this now Cynthia. A cab stops.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: We should talk. Can you just think about the idea of making a change?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I‘1l think about anything. I’11l think about shaving my head and joining a monastery but I can tell you the answer is no.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Consider it. Please. I’m not talking about joining a monastery. We could just get off the treadmill and move to Vermont and open a B&B. It could be that easy.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Fine, I’1l consider it. But honestly, I’m okay Cynthia. I really am. (sees a guy try and take his cab) No! That’s my cab!! Back off asshole!  35 36 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 27. He grabs the guy and yanks him out of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone walking in and out of the Morgan Stanley buildin on their Blackberries. Mark gets out of his cab while finishing a conversation with his cab driver.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: And remember, get out of that mutual fund you’re in. They’re going to rape you with fees! He walks into the building and passes a Morgan Stanley hi up KATHY TAO.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: Hello Mark Baum!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hey Kathy. You busted me. I had an afternoon personal thing.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: I’m not your baby sitter. If FrontPoint makes Morgan Stanley money I’m happy!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hey did I hear you’re expecting?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: We’re expecting to be expecting! The IVFs are cleaning us out but we're staying positive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small. Provisional. A tiny SUPPORT STAFF. There are four desks with Mark’s team working at each. Mark enters, pushing open the door that reads “FrontPoint Partners.”

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hey! Cynthia wants me to quit and open a B&B in Vermont! VINNY DANIEL, a Queens city school graduate in a Macy’s s turns from his desk.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 28.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY DANIEL
dialogues.text: I'd love to see Mark Baum run a B&B. “Here’s your steel cut oatmeal asshole!”

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because he didn’t kiss the ring of the people with the check books Mark Baum had to set up his fund under Morgan Stanley’s umbrella. His small team reflected Mark's distrust of the system.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. She says this job is making me unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY DANIEL
dialogues.text: But you’re happy when you’re unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Vinny Daniel: Mark’s numbers guy. Vinny lost his Father to violent crime when he was young. Just like Mark he didn’t talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY DANIEL
dialogues.text: (to camera) I don’t talk about it. An athletic Wasp, PORTER COLLINS, 31. who wears a suit ja and polo shirt, covers his blue tooth to chime in.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER COLLINS
dialogues.text: Cynthia doesn’t mess around. She got me to stop eating gluten. You want me to check the residential real estate market in Vermont!?

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Porter Collins: former Olympic rower who went to Brown. He had worked with Baum at a previous firm and couldn’t figure out why no one listened to Baum, the guy with all the good ideas.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: There’s no way I’m moving to Vermont. Westchester maybe, but not Vermont...  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 29. DANNY MOSES (31) Southern but moving fast towards New Yor a self-effacing analyst type, though he's actually their trader. HE’S FINISHING A PHONE CALL.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY MOSES
dialogues.text: +. wait a minute. I think you have the wrong FrontPoint. There’s another FrontPoint in this same building that is bonds.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Danny Moses: the optimist of the bunch. And a hell of a trader, which is why they tolerated the optimism.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay... No problem. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was a weird call.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Why? Did the person actually enjoy talking to you?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It was this guy from Deutsche who was talking about shorting housing bonds. In the middle of the call I realize he’s got the wrong FrontPoint. He wanted the one of the eighth floor.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: He wanted to short housing bonds? Who bets against housing? (due diligence) What’s the ABX at?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: What’s the ABX?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: It tracks sub-prime mortgage bond value. Danny checks his computer.  37 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 30.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s down... Wow. That’s weird. It’s down three points since last year. I haven’t heard a peep about that.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What was this guy’s name again?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jared Vennett. From Deutsche. He sounded pretty sketchy. One of the ASSISTANTS (the real DANNY MOSES) LOOKS UP TO CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: This actually happened. I’m the real Danny Moses. A wrong number led us to one of the biggest leads in investment history. I still work in New York and I wasn’t that much of an optimist.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: Call him back. Tell him we want to hear his presentation..

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: You wanna take advice from a trader we don't know -- about a market we don't understand -- cause the idiot dialed a wrong number?

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: If he'd even show up, it'd be to screw us.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared Vennett, his Chinese Quantitative Analyst, TED JIAN and a Deutsche YOUNG SALES REP stand and sit in front of room.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 31. Mark, Porter, Vinny and Danny listen to the bond trader's spiel, which is condescending and very sharp. The Deutsche Rep hands out hard copies.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: So how many people have you talked to about this trade?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: A few. And there’s definitely some interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAYING “NO” “GET LOST JARED” “YOU’RE HIGH” ETC.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: (sarcasm) Which is why you’re here talking to us, a wrong number.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: Look, some people have called me in to just laugh at me on this deal. Is that what this is?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: That’s not what this is. That’s just Mark. We wanna hear this.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: Okay, here we go... On the table is a JENGA GAME of stacked wooden blocks. On side of the blocks is written the ratings of the tiers AA AA, BBB, BB, and B. JARED VENNETT (CONT’D) This is a basic mortgage bond. The original ones were simple, thousands of AAA mortgages bundled together and sold with a guarantee from the US government. But the modern day ones are private and are made up of layers of tranches, with the AAA highest rated getting paid first and the lowest, B rated getting paid last and taking on defaults first. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 31a. JARED VENNETT (CONT’D) Obviously if you’re buying B levels you can get paid more. Hey, they’re risky, so sometimes they fail... one of the B blocks into a TRASH CAN.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: But somewhere along the line these B and BB level tranches went from risky to dog shit. I’m talking rock bottom Fico scores, no income verification, adjustable rates... Dog shit. Default rates are already up from 1 to 4 percent. If they rise to 8 percent, and they will, a lot of these BBB's are going to zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared chucks another B block and a BB in the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that, my friends, is an opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You're sure of the math? Jared gestures to his CHINESE QUANT, sitting to his right Ted turns

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Jiang is my quant. Look at him, he doesn't even speak English. He won a national math competition in China. China. Yeah I’m sure of the math. to camera.

dialogues.speaker: TED JIANG
dialogues.text: Actually I do speak English. Jared likes to say I don’t because he thinks it makes me seem more authentic. And I finished second in the national math competition. Some people at work think Jared’s a dick but he’s great at his job.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: So you're offering us the chance to short that pile of blocks? How?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: With something called a credit default swap. It’s like insurance on the bond. And if it goes bust you can make a 10 to 1, even 20 to 1 return. And it’s already slowly going bust. But no one’s paying attention cause all the banks are busy getting paid obscene amounts of fees selling these bonds. Basically I'm standing in front of a burning house and offering you fire insurance on it. Danny's trying to get his head around Jared’s numbers.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How can the underlying bonds in these pools be as bad as you say? They wouldn't be legal.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 33.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: No one knows what's in these bonds. I've seen some that are 65% AAA rated that are actually full of 95 percent subprime shit with Ficos below 550.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here!

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: And now get ready to really have your mind blown. I just discovered this treat...

dialogues.speaker: TED JIANG
dialogues.text: (to camera) We discovered it. But that’s fine. He’s on a roll.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: ...-when the market deems some bond too risky to buy, what do you think happens to it? We just warehouse them on our books?! No. They get repackaged, with a whole bunch of other shit that didn't sell, into a cDO.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: A what? Jared takes a bunch of the BBB, BB and B rated blocks and makes a precarious NEW tower.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: A collateralized debt obligation. A C-D-O. We put a bunch of unsold B, BB or BBB bonds together, when the pile gets large enough, the whole thing's considered diversified and the whores at the ratings agencies rate it 92, 93% AAA. No questions asked.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Holy hell... Say that again. FREEZE: Mark, leaning forward completely engaged.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 33a.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Collateralized debt obligation. It’s important to understand because it’s what allowed a housing crisis to become a nation wide economic disaster. So here is world famous chef Anthony Bourdain to explain.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 34. 40 INT. CHEF’S KITCHEN - DAY 40 In a high end professional kitchen ANTHONY BOURDAIN opens fridge with a bunch of fish in it.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY BOURDAIN
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m a chef on a Sunday afternoon setting the night’s menu at a big restaurant. I ordered my fish on Friday which is the mortgage bond that Michael Burry shorted. But some of the fresh fish doesn’t sell. I don’t know why, maybe it just came out halibut has the intelligence of a dolphin. So what am I going to do, throw all this unsold old fish, which is the BBB level of the bond, in the garbage and take the loss? Bourdain chops up the old fish and pushes it into the big of “SEAFOOD STEW.” ANTHONY BOURDAIN (CONT’D) No way. Being the crafty and morally onerous chef that I am, whatever crappy levels of the bond I don’t sell I throw into a “sea food stew.” See, it’s not old fish. It’s a whole new thing! And no one knows they're eating three day old halibut. That is a CDO. 4l INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - CONTINUOUS 41

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, so the mortgage bonds are dog shit but the CDOs are dog shit wrapped in garbage?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Institutions treat these CDOs like they’re as solid as treasury bonds and these things are going to zero.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That can’t be right. There were 500 billion in housing bonds sold last year alone. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The banks, the ratings agencies, the government... They wouldn’t let this happen.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: They would and they did. My whole department is long this stuff. The pricks are calling me Chicken Little and Bubble boy. But when reality hits the idiots in my department won’t be laughing. He starts pulling blocks out of the CDO and MBS towers an throwing them in the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Triple B’s? Zero. Double B's? Zero. B's? Zero. On this last one, the table shakes... both towers collaps

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then that happens.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: That is Aermcia’s housing market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinny, Danny and Porter cluster unhappily at their desk. 42 They watch Mark say good-bye to the Deutsche Bank team at door. He's lost in thought as he returns.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: He's playing us. He's dumping his position.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What if he's right?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: You want him to be right!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. When a bank offers a loan, people take it. Why? Because they assume banks know more about money than they do. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Banks have spent decades training us to let them handle our money and credit. How else do they get away with credit cards that keep you in debt for years? Student loan rates that you never get free of? Financing, for many Americans, is just a fancy term for getting raped. Then this guy walks in my office... tells me those same banks got greedy... lost track of the market ...and I can now profit off their stupidity? Fuck yeah, I want him to be right.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Things can't be as bad as he says out there.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Let's find out. That's our job.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Why don't you hate this guy? He's everything you taught us not to trust.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I can't hate him. He's so transparent in his self interest I kind of respect him. Would I buy a car from him? No way. Is he right about the mortgage market? Let's find out. (the others moan) Look, it's two very simple questions. Is there a housing bubble? And if there is, how exposed are the banks? Mark’s team can't resist him when he's in adventure mode.  43 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 37.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Sure. Vinny pfiffs his concession.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: And let’s move fast. If Vennett’s right, it’s only a matter of time before every loser with a few million bucks in a fund jumps on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: A rap song with a great beat and attitude like GRI by NELLY JAMIE SHIPLEY, 30, good looking but earnest and CHARLIE GELLER, 31, very smart and neurotic are dancing on a danc floor in a high end Chelsea club. WOMEN COME TO HANDSOME Jamie but his horrible dancing soo chases them away TO Charlie who tries to impress.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey ladies! I’m Charlie! This is Jamie! The WOMEN move away. MOMENTS LATE: Charlie and Jamie approach a table full of ATTRACTIVE MANHATTAN PROFESSIONAL WOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (yelling over the music) Hi ladies! I’m Charlie . This is Jamie!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hi! I’m Jamie!

dialogues.speaker: ATTRACTIVE MANHATTAN PROFESSIONAL
dialogues.text: How can we help you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'll just be straight with you. No games. The truth is, you all are very attractive and we wanted to get to know you!  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 37A.

dialogues.speaker: ATTRACTIVE MANHATTAN PROFESSIONAL
dialogues.text: Get the fuck away from us!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay! Jamie starts to sit down with them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! They said fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Ooh! Jamie jumps up and they leave.  44 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Jamie sit nervous under massive Richter works

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: JP Morgan. Can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Okay, don’t make me nervous. They're just people. Finally, they hear...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Brownfield Fund? They stand, straighten their suits. A BOY BANKER hurries from behind the reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You must be Ted!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER
dialogues.text: No, I'm Chris. I'm on Ted's desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh. I’m Charlie. Charlie Geller.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Jamie Shipley. We’re excited to get set up on your trading platform.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER
dialogues.text: Cool. Here, guys, have a seat a second. He gestures to the chairs they just stood from. Not good. YOUNG BANKER (CONT’D) Ted asked me to do some meeting prep but I couldn't find any marketing material on you.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 39-40.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry. We don't have any. We recently moved here from Colorado.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER
dialogues.text: Got it. Can we see your offering documents?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (sheepish) Brownfield is all our own money.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER
dialogues.text: Well, can you tell us how much you manage?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sure. It's 30 million, but we started four years ago with 110 thousand. So, our returns have been pretty phenomenal.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We want to get an ISDA agreement with JP Morgan so we can deal in long term options.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER
dialogues.text: That's cool. But you're under the capital requirements for an ISDA.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Like, by how much?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER
dialogues.text: One billion four hundred seventy million. Jamie and Charlie flinch.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Does it make us look bad that we didn’t know what the capital requirements were?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER
dialogues.text: It’s not great. Awkward beat. YOUNG BANKER (CONT’D) Have a good one guys. He walks away.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 Al.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: B of A and Bear didn’t return our calls and even Wachovia blew us off. 30 million means nothing to these banks. They keep calling us “high net worth individuals.”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Here’s the prospectuses and brochures of all the other losers who didn’t get past the lobby. There are scattered brochures and folders with names like “The Nostradamus Fund” and “The Long Short Group.” Under is Jared Vennett’s “Shorting the Housing Market.”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look... This guy’s saying the housing market is a massive bubble... Jamie LOOKS TO CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We didn’t really find Jared Vennett’s housing bubble pitch in the lobby of a bank that rejected us. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 46 47 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 42.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The truth is, a friend told Charlie about it. And I read about it in Grant’s Interest Rate Observer. But this is more fun.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This guy says there are 10 to l returns on credit default swaps on mortgage backed securities. He says they whole housing market will collapse... Freeze.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For Jamie and Charlie , the housing market doomsday prediction was music to their ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CRAPPY GARAGE with computer paper on the wall reading “ Brownfield Fund” It’s hot as Jamie and Charlie work on th lap tops. Jamie pours water over his head. A CHOCOLATE LA sleeps on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They had started working out of Jamie's garage with 110 thousand Jamie had saved taking sailboats up and down the east coast. Their strategy was simple and brilliant...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: People hate to think about bad things happening so they underestimate their likelihood.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Holy shit. That’s like the most brilliant thing you’ve ever said!  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 42a.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Jamie and Charlie found banks will sell options very cheaply on things they think will never ever happen. When they were wrong, they were wrong small. But when they were right, they were right big. Within a a few years they had turned their 110 grand into 30 million. But then it was time to go to NYC. And so far, it wasn’t going well.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: So what if it does seem interesting. No bank will give us our ISDA. We’re dead in the water.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think we should call Ben.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREEZE: WE CUT TO BEN RICKERT, 45, and the most neurotic person we've met so far, walking his dog with Jamie on A RESIDENTIAL STREET or PARK.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ben Rickert was a former trader in Singapore for Chase who had quit the whole game in disgust. He happened to be Jamie’s neighbor when they were in Colorado and they met walking dogs. But Ben was dark. He didn’t just think the whole system would fail, he thought the whole world was going down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see hands putting down jugs of water next to a dozen j of water in a kitchen. It’s Jamie and Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey Ben! Do you think you have enough water?

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Average precipitation in this region is down 2% a year for the past eight years! And Congress just cut the budget to police loose nukes!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: God he’s paranoid. Ben enters.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Not paranoid. Prepared.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ben had real experience in a big bank. Jamie and Charlie had never even been in a Manhattan bank bathroom. But Ben was done with the banking world. He was very clear.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Look, there really could be something here. But it’s pretty bold, so let’s do some digging before we call Ben.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (Still perusing the pitch). Wow. This is pretty shocking. It’s like it’s all hidden in plain sight...

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Seriously guys! I need you out of here! Now!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CU: The hilarious scowl of the MIAMI DOLPHINS LOGO. INT. TERMINAL —- MIAMI AIRPORT - DAY 52 Porter and Danny pass a shop with the Dolphins logo on ev conceivable domestic item. They're on a mission, one they sure is a waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: One time Mark sent me to Indiana for a week to check out an air conditioner factory. He thought they were using inferior materials. They weren't.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Come on, it’s not so bad. It’s Florida. Besides, I never get to travel. Let’s have fun.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Don’t be chipper in the face of me being miserable. Please. It makes me hate you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t being chipper. Beat as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe we can get some Cuban food. I hear it’s amazing in Miami.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 44a.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’m serious Danny. Knock it off.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How is wanting to eat chipper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter and Danny get out of a rental car and consider a FAILED DEVELOPMENT. Four model houses sit alone, closed f business, their perfect yards surrounded by cyclone fenci  54 55 56 57 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 45.

dialogues.speaker: STREET LIGHTS NOW COME ON ACROSS THE EMPTY AND HALF FINIS
dialogues.text: SUBDIVISION. Danny and Porter are puzzled, and intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s like they just walked away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-hundred eager PARTICIPANTS attend a seminar called, " Can Be a Real Estate Millionaire!"

dialogues.speaker: SEMINAR LEADER
dialogues.text: Real estate is the only entrepreneurial activity available to all Americans. Why? Simple, it doesn't require capital. That's right. Let me say that again. You don't need money to be a real estate millionaire! In the back, Porter sips a hotel takeaway cup, stunned, appalled. Danny takes notes. An EAGER GREETER spots them. She slips out.

dialogues.speaker: GREETER
dialogues.text: Hello gentlemen. Are you interested in the 10 CD set? Only 2999 dollars!

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: We're good! Thank you. Porter and Danny slip away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny knocks like someone knocking for the last time. No answer. He looks in the mail slot... the house is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Covered in old newspapers. Porter checks one for a date. three months old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny peers in a front window. This time, the door OPENS. sleepy MAN WITH A TATTOOED NECK rubs his eyes.  58 59 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 46.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh. Hello. I'm surveying mortgage owners who are over 90 days delinquent. I'm looking for a... Harvey Humpsey?

dialogues.speaker: TATTOOED NECK
dialogues.text: You want my landlord's dog?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Your landlord filled out his mortgage using his dog’s name?

dialogues.speaker: TATTOOED NECK
dialogues.text: I guess so. Hold up, has that asshole not been paying his mortgage? Cause I’m paying my rent.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He is 90 days late on his payments, yes.

dialogues.speaker: TATTOOED NECK
dialogues.text: Seriously, am I going to have to leave? There's fear in his eyes, the last thing Danny expected. CHILD now appears between the big man's legs. TATTOOED NECK (CONT’D) Cause my kid just got settled in the school.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Um. I don’t know. You should talk to your landlord. Sorry. Have a good day! The man stays at the door as Danny hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Danny and Porter peer in... the place is abandoned; its few modest furnishings, covered in dust.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Hello?! Anybody here?! Hola?! Yo?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter tries a light switch, dead.  60 61 62 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 47. A CORKBOARD above a desk still has post-its. The carpet i covered with files, books, a box of old photos.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: The only thing they took was their Tv! He picks up a dusty TIME MAGAZINE with Greenspan/Summers/ Rubin on the cover. "The Committee to Save the World".

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White bread molds in the bag. At the counter, Porter watches Danny shows the old mortga bill: the house's owner used a black marker to circle the amount due and then wrote... SORRY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back yard is over grown and the pool is murky green.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I think I saw three houses in the whole development with cars in the driveway. Suddenly something swirls in the pool and they see a 10 F ALLIGATOR emerge and submerge.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Holy... fucking... shit.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY IS VISIBLE IN THE WINDOW OF A CUBAN RESTAURANT EATI
dialogues.text: Porter is outside on the sidewalk on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Hey Mark, you might want to get down here.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 63 64 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan past Scion’s office which is now littered with emp desks and land on the WHITE BOARD showing last quarter’s returns: -9.3%. Two ANALYSTS talk to each other from their desks gossipin while Burry in his office works on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: ANALYST
dialogues.text: I heard he had a breakdown. He’s letting the fund tank.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: A buddy of mine in Manhattan said Burry left his wife and is moving to Peru. A PHONE RINGS at Burry’s ASSISTANT’S DESK.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE'S ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: (answers the phone) ) Scion. Dr. Burry's office. .--He would prefer you email him...I sit twenty feet away and I email him-- The FRONT DOOR opens. Lawrence Fields and MARTIN BLAINE (45) of Metro Capital enter. 2 thousand dollar sport coats and polo shirts. They stride right for Mike's office. MIKE'S ASSISTANT sta to email Burry furiously, gives up, stands.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE'S ASSISTANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (loudly) Mr. Fields. Mr. Blaine. Hello. They enter Mike's office, shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ANALYST
dialogues.text: Was that Lawrence Fields? Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawrence sits. Martin stands. They're angry. Yet, Mike, i shirt, shirts with no shoes, doesn't seem to even registe there's any emotion here at all.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 49.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Your big mortgage bet concerns us. We have no confidence in your ability to identify macroeconomic trends.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You flew here to tell me that? Why? I mean, anyone can see there's a real estate bubble.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Actually, no one can see a bubble... that's what makes it a bubble.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: That's dumb, Lawrence. There are always markers. Mortgage fraud. It's quintupled since 2000. Average take home pay is flat yet home prices are soaring. That means the homes are debt not assets.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN BLAINE
dialogues.text: So, Mike Burry of San Jose, a guy who gets his hair cut at Super Cuts and doesn’t wear shoes, knows more than Alan Greenspan and Hank Paulson?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Dr. Mike Burry. And, yes. He does.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Are you being sarcastic with us, Michael?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I don't know how to be sarcastic. I don't know how to be funny. I don't know how to work people. I know how to read numbers. Okay, let's talk numbers. Lawrence changes tack.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: How big's your short position? Right now?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It's 1.3 billion.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 50.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: And the premiums?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We pay roughly 80 to 90 million every year. (they wince) I know it's high but I was the first one to do this trade. It will pay. Watch. I may have been early, but I'm not wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN BLAINE
dialogues.text: It's the same thing! Lawrence raises a finger to ask his partner for restraint

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: You're managing, what, a fund of 555 million? (Mike nods) In 6 years it'll all be gone. On one bet.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Second quarter of 07’ the adjustable rates will kick in and defaults will sky rocket.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN BLAINE
dialogues.text: Says you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: How much is eligible for withdrawal before they do, say in the next two quarters? (then) If your investors panic.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It's 302 million.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: My God, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No one will pull out! It'd be suicide! Yeah, I'm down 17 percent for the year, but if they trust me--

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN BLAINE
dialogues.text: No one trusts you.  65 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 51.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I've written several emails to the investors letting them know second quarter of 07’ is when our position on housing shows returns. I've been very clear. He sounds like a crazy man defending himself to a tree.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: There will be redemptions.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, that would be really stupid. (angry) If the fund's capital drops too much, the swaps contracts are voided. And the banks get to keep the collateral!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN BLAINE
dialogues.text: What? They didn't know this, and it seals the deal.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE FIELDS
dialogues.text: Give us our money back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUMPERSTICKER: “Pricing gets traffic, staging gets offers The sticker's on a brand new...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gets a house tour from a wealthy REAL ESTATE AGENT. MUSIC: A dreamy samba like SO NICE by BEBEL GILBERTO

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: The market's in an itsy-bitsy little gully right now. It's like everybody said, "Okay, that was crazy. Let's all just slow down." A YOUNGER AGENT sits in the back between Danny and Porter Mark’s engrossed by the upper-middle-class world out the window; Every driveway has a new SUV, or odd Prius. Every garage has a Winnebago, jet ski, speed boat. Complicated riding mowers. Trampolines. Plundered Ebay and Amazon box  66 67 68 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 52. And, yet, there are For Sale signs everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attractive brick house, exhaustively landscaped. In fa the harried HOMEOWNER is now edging his lawn.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I sold it the year it was built for 350.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MERCEDES SUV
dialogues.text: The SUV has stopped at a discreet distance.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: Two years later for 480. Then...585 maybe... only 18 months later. This couple bought it last year for 650, he'd let it go for that. He spots her. Come show it! She waves back. Not today!

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It'll break his heart, but he'll let it go.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Why's he selling?

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: Neither one's working right now.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER AGENT
dialogues.text: Marlene, you'd say they're motivated, right?

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: As much as one can be in this neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. SUV
dialogues.text: SHOTS of the SUV driving them past big houses for sale.  69 70 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 53.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: House on the left might be motivated...That is another quasi- motivated seller...They're probably teensy-weensy bit motivated...In her case I'd say possibly almost motivated. Danny and Porter exchange a look. The market's in trouble

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: A lot of homeowners seem pretty motivated.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: It's the gully. That's all. Just nerves. (faces Mark) So... where are we?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Let me talk to my wife.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER AGENT
dialogues.text: This market won't last.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Actually, can I talk with a mortgage broker? Anyone you like?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Bitch better like me, I sent her to Cabo. The bar's empty save Mark, Danny and Porter sitting with overly-groomed MORTGAGE BROKERS -- their ties match their shirts: the hip one's in BLACK; his friend, MAROON. The guy in Maroon has Porter's business card.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Is Morgan Stanley recruiting us?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: The bank owns our hedge fund but we're not really part of it. We invest in financial service companies. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're here trying to understand the residential mortgage business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brokers just nod, glad to be part of the conversation

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: How many loans do you write each month?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: It's about 60. Maroon nods. Me, too. Almost.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What was it four years ago?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Ten. Maybe 15.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: I was a bartender.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How many are adjustable rate mortgages?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Most. Ninety percent. The bonuses on those sky rocketed a few years ago. Adjustable is our bread and honey.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: These are people buying a primary residence?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: No, they're all cash-out refi's, or property to flip. A shitload of condos. A few primaries.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do mortgage applicants ever get turned down? They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Dude, if they get rejected I suck at my job.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Even if they have no money?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 55.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Well, my firm offers NINJA loans. No Income. No Job. I just leave the income section blank if I want, corporate doesn't care. And the people just want a house. So they go with the flow.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: We call those loans “Dorothys” cause they’re magic. No credit, no income, no problem: just tap your shoes together three times and say “There’s nothing like owning a home.”

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Your companies don't verify?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: If I write a loan on Friday afternoon, the big banks buy it by Monday lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Same here.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Can you two hold on a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyeing the brokers, Mark whispers with Porter and Danny.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I don't get it. Why are they confessing?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's not confessing.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: They're bragging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes an ottoman right in front of the brokers.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Do customers ever know what they're buying?  73 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 56.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: I focus my business on immigrants. Once you tell them they’re getting a home they sign where you tell them to sign, don't ask questions, don't really understand the rates. Mark starts to say something, then turns to Black.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You target immigrants, too?

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Ha! Their credit isn't bad enough for him!

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I'm a yield guy. I make 2,000 on fixed-rate prime loans. I can make 10,000 on a subprime adjustable. Trust me, I would not be driving a Hummer without Strippers. Nobody on the pole has good credit. And they're all cash rich. Porter and Danny watch Mark consider punching this punk. last thing they expect is...

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Can you introduce us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: A sexy pop song like SEXYBACK by JUSTIN TIMBERLAKE

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I always get option-pay adjustables. I'm a private contractor. I need flexibility. A DANCER does rote gyrations. Mark’s indifferent to the l dance, unashamed, occupied by his agenda.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You tell the mortgage company what you do?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I write therapist. (and then) You can touch me.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 57.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Always?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Only in the VIP.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: No, you said you always do adjustables. You have more than one loan on a property?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Everybody does. At least down here. That way you only put down like 5 percent.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: But prices have leveled off.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Yeah, there's a gully.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Can you stop moving? I'll still pay you. She peeks out of the alcove, sees a BURLY MAN WITH A HARD FACE and keeps dancing.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Sorry, (mouthing it) we're not alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Okay, look, if home prices don't rise you won't be able to refinance. You'll be stuck with whatever your monthly payment jumps to after the teaser rate expires. Plus any payments you missed. Plus interest on those payments! Your monthly could go up 200 or 300 percent!

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Jamie says I can always refinance.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: He's lying. Actually, in this particular case, Jamie's probably just wrong.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 57A.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Two hundred percent? On all my loans?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 58.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What do you mean all my loans? We're talking about two loans on one house, right? She stops and gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I have five houses. And a condo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of purpose, Mark strides ahead of Porter and Danny.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Get the mortgage exposure and leverage ratio of every bulge bracket i-bank-- (into his phone) --Hey, there's a bubble.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Trust me. Call Vennett. Buy 50 million in swaps on the MBS... Danny holds out the offering doc.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Garabaldi IV. Triple B.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You sure, Mark?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's time to call bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bullshit on what?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
