dialogues.text: Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared Vennett is running on a treadmill when the phone ri  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 59.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: (on his cell) Is this America's angriest hedge fund?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How are you, JARED? Jared steps off the treadmill to take the call.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Starting to believe my own hype.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I've got one last question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinny on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: How are you fucking us? Jared cackles.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm serious. We'll buy your swaps. But only if you say how you're fucking us.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared steps away from a few guys working out.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Swaps are a dark market. That means I set the price. Whatever price I want. When you come back for your pay day I'll rip your eyes out and make a fortune. The good news for you is you'll make so much you won’t care. Plus your boss has a big mouth and I need people to know about this trade so my superiors don’t think it’s an esoteric waste of time and I can keep selling it. Static.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 59A.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank you.  78

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Anytime. (then) What's it gonna be? You want me to make you a market?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. We'll take 50 million-- He disconnects, punches air. His casual pose evaporates.

dialogues.speaker: BOULDER COLORADO
dialogues.text: Can be stock footage showing mountains and the town of Boulder. We hear a phone ringing. INT. BEN RICKERT’S HOME OFFICE - BOULDER COLORADO - DAY B

dialogues.speaker: APRIL 2006
dialogues.text: 2 years 4 months until the collapse CU on a cell phone ringing on a desk. A hand fumbles for and answers.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hello? It’s Ben Rickert. His office has three computer screens showing the Japanese markets, the Dow, Nasdaq, weather satellite images and tidal charts.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey Ben. It’s Jamie-

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I told you not to call this number. He hangs up. After a beat a satellite phone rings. Ben answers.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hate when you do that. No one’s listening to your calls Ben. You're a retired trader.  79 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 60A.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Really? So the NSA has a 52 billion dollar budget and the ability to monitor 10’s of millions of calls a second but they’re not using it?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Okay fine. We’1l call this number and I’1l stop saying “Ben Rickert” and “dirty bomb” in the same conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Seriously don’t do that. That’s not funny.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did you read what we sent you?! It’s Charlie! I’m here too!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hey guys. Yeah, I checked out what you sent me... Hold on... Ben picks up a bootleg copy of Jared's PRESENTATION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brick loft. Jamie and Charlie are gathered around a pho on speaker. We cut back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.0)
dialogues.text: I’1ll be honest gentlemen... It scared the shit out me.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 61.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So this guy Vennett’s not wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No... he’s not.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.0)
dialogues.text: Tell me more about these CDOs... I feel like I opened the hood of a car and instead of an engine saw a monkey on a bike. Ben holds up a report Jamie and Charlie did on CDOs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Vennett mentions the CDOs but they’re way worse than even he knows. We couldn’t even model them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They don’t make any sense! And they’re a hundred times larger than the MBS!

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And somehow they’re over 90% AAA rated. The perfect scam.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I‘ll be honest. I don’t love that these losers are saying I missed something but the truth is they’re right. The CDOs were a hundred times worse than even I imagined. Let’s go back to Bourdain’s seafood stew so we’re all on the same page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourdain stands over the pot of seafood stew.

dialogues.speaker: BOURDAIN
dialogues.text: Alright, remember how I said the CDOs are seafood stew filled with old fish stamped AAA? Well Jamie and Charlie found out the CDOs were even worse than that. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 61a.

dialogues.speaker: BOURDAIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Turns out they were filled with shitty mortgages from different bonds that didn’t even operate by the same laws. And there were also swaps and all kinds of other junk just thrown in there. Millions and millions of this garbage... So instead of just old fish our seafood stew also has... wolverine meat in it... He puts a weird gray meat in.

dialogues.speaker: BOURDAIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Possum... skunk... Kimodo dragon and then a whole lot of stuff the no one even knows what it is. Bourdain reaches into a box marked simply MEAT (?) and th a bunch in.

dialogues.speaker: BOURDAIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And these CDOs were selling and selling.... Wee pull out and see dozens of pots of stew all around th kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: BOURDAIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nuts, right?

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I saw the CDOs you want to short. The're brilliant. Worthless, total crap.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Jamie Shipley, Ladies and Gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I'm good at finding shit. If I can keep Charlie from trying to sneak in a little value.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sue me, I'm Jewish. We shorted all double BBs and triple B’s. The risk is relatively low and the pay off is 25 to l.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 61B.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So why are you calling me? I don’t do this anymore. Charlie and Jamie share a careful glance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Look, Ben, help us get an ISDA so we can short this crap. We know you hate Wall Street but it's not like you'd be trading, you'd only be helping us get a place at the table.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That’s an ugly table to be seated at.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The system fucked up in a big, big way here. And somehow we know before anyone else. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a once in a lifetime trade. Help us make this deal. Come on, it’1l be fun.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh this won’t be fun. Sam's tone is less than definite, he's clearly tempted.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean fun.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You said fun. Beat

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll call Deutsche Bank. Charlie and Jamie high five.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. What about Bear? They have some reprehensible product.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay. Bear will trade with anybody. Silent air pumps.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: How soon can you be out here?

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know... I haven’t flown since they put those Chertoff body scanners in the airports. I've never been a fan of being strip searched by radiation. (takes a breath) I’ll be there Tuesday. Jamie and Charlie celebrate more. MUSIC: An popular alternative hip hop song like FEEL GOOD by GORILLAZ plays us into the next scene. c80 INT. KENNEDY AIRPORT TERMINAL - DAY c80 Ben rides the long airport escalator wearing a flu mask. holding a duffle bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 62a. He passes an Asian man also wearing a flu mask, salutes h comrade-in-fear. The man stares back confused. At the bottom of the escalator Charlie and Jamie wait wit sign reading “Ben Rickert” Ben walks past them with out breaking stride and crumples the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Jamie sign an ISDA CONTRACT in the lobby. Ben waits over them. NOAH, 26, Vennett’s assistant takes contract.

dialogues.speaker: NOAH
dialogues.text: All right. I'll see if I can push it through.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Noah. And thank Jared for us. Charlie and Jamie stand. Noah goes. The boys exchange an unsure look. What now? Ben gestures to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You know, just once in my life, I'd like to see the inside of an investment bank.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So that’s it Ben? We’re done?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That’s it. Between Bear and Duetsche, you now officially own 12 million dollars of credit default swaps on the BBB- tranches of subprime ABS’.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Somehow I thought it would be more dramatic.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: So what'd we do now?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 62B. Ben doesn’t break stride.  81 82 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 63.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Now we wait for the world to blow up.

dialogues.speaker: QUOTE COMES UP OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: “THE TRUTH WILL SET YOU FREE. BUT NOT UNTIL IT IS DONE WI YOU.” -DAVID FOSTER WALLACE, INFINITE JEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An electronic scroll on the side of Morgan Stanley reads: Mortgage Delinquencies Hit New High

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: January 11, 2007 1 year 7 months until the collapse We hear snippets of business news audio:

dialogues.speaker: SNIPPETS OF BUSINESS NEWS
dialogues.text: Ben Bernanke calls the news a momentary market fluctuation.... Despite the disappointing housing news all other market indicators are very strong.... Mark Baum is running down the street while dialing his ph and trying to hail a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hello! Vinny Daniel please! A CAB STOPS, he gets in.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Morgan Stanley building. Fast.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: (feint voice on the cell) Hello? Mark is that you?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Vinny! Did you see?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinny is walking through the FrontPoint offices. Danny, Porter and the rest of the staff are on the phones.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mortgage defaults just went through the roof! Is anybody jumping off buildings?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Why would they? Subprime mortgage bond prices are up. We see emails on Vinny’s screen from Duetsche notifying t the bond’s value is up. “Garabaldi IV: BBB tranche”

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What?! Porter turns over his shoulder from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Vennett is asking for more collateral on our swaps!

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on?!

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: We don't know. But Deutsche is on the phone demanding payment.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Somebody call Vennett. (Porter does so) Subprime loans go bad... but subprime bonds get more valuable?!

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: They want another 2 million by market close.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What about the rating’s agencies? Are Moody’s and S&P downgrading CDOs or mortgage bonds?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Nope. They’re all still triple A.  84

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Motherfuckers! 2015 64a. 84  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 65. The West African CAB DRIVER looks over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: Is everything okay sir?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah, other than the fact America is a cesspool of corruption and greed.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: That is very true sir! But I never hear Americans say it! Haha!

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That’s not all Mark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinny peers into their Conference Room, where there are T RISK MANAGERS. Standing at the head of the table is a ver pregnant, Kathy Tao.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: The Frontpoint risk guys are here. They called in Kathy Tao. They're trying to convince her to make us to sell our swaps. Apparently, tying up 6 years of insurance payments in hopes of housing Armageddon is not good investing.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What'd Kathy say?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Nothing, yet. She keeps asking if this is one of your crusades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: When she leaves, go back in and very calmly, very politely, tell the risk assessors to fuck off. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 88 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 66.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then meet me over at Standard and Poors. Let's go talk to Georgia Hale. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: In my country they just show up and steal your children for their army. In America they are very sneaky. They take your house, your money and you still think they are your friends!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You want a job?

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: No way brother! I am just the ferryman! Haha! He drives crazy fast through traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinny enters. The risk managers go silent.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: (calmly, politely) Mark said to fuck off. The Risk Managers wait for nuance. None will be coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael Burry writes on the big white board the quarterly returns: -11.3%. There are now only five working analysts The rest of the desks are empty. Michael walks into his office closes the door and yells.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Fuuuuuuuck!!!!! Everyone in the office looks up and then after a beat, go back to working.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Michael?  89 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 67. INT. MICHAEL BURRY’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - DUSK 89 Michael is watching Business News on the TV while his WIF pretty and direct, tries to talk to him. SOMEONE FROM THE TREASURY OR THE FED BEING INTERVIEWED. She turns

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL, (SOT)
dialogues.text: Yes, there’s been an up tick in defaults but it’s well within our models.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL, (SOT)
dialogues.text: So despite these temporary aberrant numbers we're quite pleased.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Michael! off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m trying to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I was listening. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: The school says Nicholas has been having issues. He’s not socializing. He isolates and doesn’t communicate with the other kids. NICHOLAS his six year old son is playing with a toy crane the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (listing parts of the crane) Hoist rope, lattice boom, upper sheave, gantry, harnass...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Well I was never the most social of kids... Is that such a bad thing?  90 91 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 68.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: They think we should take him to a specialist to get an evaluation.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Then yes, of course, let’s do that.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad... Nicholas has walked over to them holding his toy crane.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The crane is rotating 260 degrees. It just needed a circular base and a catch for the string.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: That's great Nicholas! Good job!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: I can't see a damn thing. GEORGIA HALE (55) is a pleasant, middle-class woman weari EYE EXAM SUNSHADES and fussing with her blinds.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My eye doctor's always busy. I end up taking any appointment they'll give me and then the whole morning gets shot to hell. She goes to her desk... where Mark and Vinny wait.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alrighty. So. FrontPoint Partners. How can Standard and Poors help you?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: We don't understand why the ratings agencies aren't downgrading subprime bonds, since the underlying loans are deteriorating.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 69.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: Well, delinquency rates have people worried, but they're actually within our models.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Models that you share with the banks. Couldn’t they be gaming them?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: I highly doubt it. These are very large banks that care a great deal about their reputations.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They care a lot more about their bonuses.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: I'm sure the world's banks have more nuanced incentives than abject greed, Mr. Baum.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: Then they'll go bankrupt. The marketplace is ruthlessly efficient. Mark considers this old saw a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Your convinced the underlying mortgages in these bonds are solid loans?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: That's our opinion, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Here's what I don't understand: if these mortgage bonds are so solid why are all the stocks for the mortgage brokerage companies down? These are companies issuing the loans that make up the bonds and they're tanking. She's inscrutable behind her sunshades. But the fact she doesn't argue tells us he's shaken her confidence.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 70.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: We believe our ratings will prove accurate.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Have you ever refused to rate any of these bonds upper tranches AAA? Can we see the paper work on those deals?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: I’m not under any obligation to share that information with you.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Just answer me Georgia. Can you name one time in the past year where you checked the tape and didn’t give the banks the triple AAA percentage they wanted? Half beat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: If we deny them the rating they'll go to Moody's. A stunned beat. She's not supposed to say this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we don't work with them, they'll go to our competitors.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Holy shit. They’re selling ratings for fees. Silence. Mark didn't know it was that simple, that cynica

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You can afford to make less. Make less.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: It’s not my decision. I have a boss.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Really? That’s the angle you’re taking? So anyone who has a boss can’t be held responsible for doing shitty and illegal things? What are you, nine years old?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 TOA. She takes her glasses off. Her eyes are watery, dilated.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: And what, pray tell, are your incentives?! Why are you in my office?! Is it maybe in your interest to have the ratings change?! How many credit default swaps do you own?! She's nailed him.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: (quietly) That doesn't make me wrong.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 71.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: No, it just makes you a hypocrite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinny watches Mark as they ride back uptown in a crowd. He’s rattled.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: (checks his blackberry) Vennett’s coming to the office at 3. (then) You okay? Mark nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Short the rating agencies. All of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Jamie are climbing the walls. Ben is on speak phone.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mortgage delinquencies went up and the CDOs got more valuable!? You gotta be kidding me!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We know. It’s completely backwards. It’s like 2 plus 2 equals 73. Ag94 INT. BEN RICKERT’S OFFICE - SAME TIME Ag94 Ben sits at his desk reading the Sixth Great Extinction. cut back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I just called an old friend at Bear and he didn’t even know what a CDO is.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had to transfer Bear and Duetsche 78 thousand dollars. It’s like I bought a suit and paid for it with two suits.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 71a.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s rigged. We bought into a rigged game. We’re going to lose hundreds of thousands a year until it’s all gone and I have to move back in with my mom.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Having fun yet? Beat as Charlie catches a thought.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... We know the CDOs are taking losses and yet the price is frozen or going up. Maybe they’re frozen because the banks have no idea how to value them? I bet they’re so toxic the banks are just guessing! (half beat) I think we should buy more swaps.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What?! No way! No.  94 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared Vennett is seated in the conference room. Mark, Vin Danny and Porter are SCREAMING AT HIM. He is amazingly ca and even CHECKS HIS PHONE at one point.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: You fucked us! I knew you’d fuck us!... What game are you running! I’m calling the goddamn justice department! Don’t check your phone! Don’t you check your fucking phone! ! Finally the group is exhausted from yelling and they run of gas.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: You guys done?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think so.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (holding his side) Jesus. I think I pulled a muscle in my back from yelling.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Mortgage defaults are way up. Yet you quote us a higher price on the bonds. Tell me why we shouldn’t pull out of this trade right now?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Listen, I told you when we did this deal the ratings agencies, the SEC and the big banks are clueless. So now their foot’s on fire and they think their steak is done and you're surprised?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: This isn’t stupidity, this is fraud.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Hey, if you can tell me the difference between stupid and illegal I’1l have my wife’s brother arrested. Danny laughs. Everyone glares at him.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 72a.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. That was funny.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I just don’t think you guys realize how clueless the system is. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, there’s shady shit happening but trust me, it’s all fueled by stupidity. Face it, as cynical as you all are I think you still have a shred of respect left for the powers that be.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Okay, except Vinny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is pleading to his case.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Look, either we're wrong or we’re right in a giant, giant way! If we're right I want to go all in. If we're wrong I want someone to tell us.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’m not feeling remotely confident that we’re right. And if we're wrong, who’s going to tell us?

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sounds like we need to go to Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, Vegas. The American Securitization Forum. It’s next week. Every bond and CDO salesman, subprime lender and swap trader in the country will be there. I’m telling you, your bet is against dumb money. I think it’s time you meet that dumb money.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I hate Vegas. 73. 95 96  97 98 99 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 74.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I hear the restaurants in Vegas have gotten really good. They have a Nobu.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Fucking stop it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. VENETIAN HOTEL - STATUES —- DAY 97 CU The LIVING STATUES AT THE VENETIAN. The white classica statues are STILL FOR A BEAT and THEN MOVE AND LOOK INTO CAMERA . MUSIC: A hip hop or rap song that exudes attitude like TO IT OR NOT by CAM’RON kicks in as soon as the statues move INT. MAIN CASINO FLOOR OF CAESAR’S PALACE - DAY 98 QUICK SERIES OF IMAGES: 1) Cash being exchanged for chips A SEXY WAITRESS serving drinks with a tattoo of her baby daughter on her calf 3) A MARINE is playing two slot mach smoking and drinking. 4) A poster showing happy good look people gambling and winning. INT. TRADE SHOW FLOOR - CAESAR’S PALACE - DAY 99 A sea of sponsored booths. Familiar banks. Lots and lots White people. A BANNER tells us it's the: American Securitization Forum Ben gives Charlie and Jamie the tour. Jamie takes photos his cell. Charlie gets schooled.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And what's "midprime"?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A loan that's between prime and subprime?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Midprime's exactly the same as subprime.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That doesn't make sense.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 75.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And if a bond is “rich” it is...?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Loaded with assets?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Overpriced and you probably lose all your money. (how did he know this?) I can’t sleep on planes so I did my homework. Ben stops, turns to his proteges.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Let’s focus up. Now what's our goal here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To figure out if this is the deal of a lifetime, or if everybody knows something we don’t and we’re about to get royally screwed.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Good. Now don’t lose sight of that when you’re with the guys from Bear tomorrow morning. I set you up with a face-to-face.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where’s the meeting? Mark, Vinny, Danny and Porter enter and cross past the Brownfield Guys.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: Five years ago securitization was a loser convention. 100, maybe 200 people would show. 500 billion dollars a year later and you get this.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: A lot of smug looks in this place.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: It’s like someone hit a pinata filled with white people who suck at golf. Who are all these clowns?  100 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 76.

dialogues.speaker: MARK BAUM
dialogues.text: According to Vennett, this is who we're betting against. Vennett approaches the group with his young ASSISTANT, wh hands out room keys. Mark nods.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Hello gentlemen. My assistant Chris has your room keys. I trust your travel was uneventful?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: So when do we get face time with these charming folks?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: They'll be plenty of face time. But remember, we’re here to gather info, not advertise our short position. We don’t want to spook anyone. Got it? The group still checking out the crowded lobby.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously. Mark, you've got a very loud mouth. Can you muzzle it for a few days?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: So you don’t want me warning people that the entire conference is put on to normalize the buying and selling of worthless shit?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. We'll be good little boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICH GUY and Reps from Bear Stearns in business casual sh guns. Bullets rip into politically incorrect targets...a black attacking a sexy white woman, an Asian gangster, a big photo of Osama bin Laden.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 76A. Charlie and Jamie shoot Uzi's, surprised by how much fun they're having. Clips spent, they remove headgear.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 77.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The Beretta's great, but the Uzi... awesome!

dialogues.speaker: BEAR REP
dialogues.text: Nice shooting, Brown Holers.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Brownfield. The name of the company is Brownfield.

dialogues.speaker: BEAR REP
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. But it’s more fun to call you Brown Hole.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I get it, wow that’s really clever. Another Bear Rep #1 is about to shoot.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Matt right?

dialogues.speaker: BEAR REP
dialogues.text: (removes head phones) What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We were hoping we could get a little more insight on the CDO’s from you we’ve got swaps on.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: SO, what do you think’s gonna happen to CDO’s in seven years?

dialogues.speaker: BEAR REP
dialogues.text: 7 years? I just need this CDO machine to keep going for another 2 years. By then I’1l be rich enough to get a place in Aspen.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do you have any concerns about the performance of the underlying securitizations? It’s easy to see delinquencies and even default rates on the rise.

dialogues.speaker: BEAR REP
dialogues.text: Don't be a buzzkill, dude. We didn’t bring you guys out here to talk work, OK?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 TIA.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Then why did you?

dialogues.speaker: BEAR REP
dialogues.text: We need a client along so we can expense the ammo. Aims machine gun at a poster of thug, and fires.

dialogues.speaker: RICH BEAR REP
dialogues.text: Woooo!!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Jamie) Holy shit. These are the guys on the other side of our trade. They only care about their fees and bonuses. And they’re morons. We need to buy more shorts. Jamie checks his cell.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You hit the main floor and price some more swaps. My Brother’s ex girlfriend works at the SEC and she’s in town. If we’re missing something she can tell me.

dialogues.speaker: TWO HUNDRED OR SO BANKERS AND BOND TRADERS TAKE THEIR SEA
dialogues.text: in a large ball room with a podium at the front. A sign r “Option One CEO Paul Dantone: The Mortgage Market is Stro and Getting Stronger”

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Option One is the mortgage company last year that took a big loss in their subprime department.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I don’t get it. They sell the mortgages they make. How did they take losses?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 78.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: There’s a provision that if the owner misses the very first payment the loan goes back to Option One.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Who takes a mortgage if they can’t make the first payment?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: The real question is: what company gives a mortgage to someone who can’t make the first payment? LATER: THE CEO OF OPTION ONE is speaking to the room.

dialogues.speaker: OPTION ONE CEO
dialogues.text: ..-Business is good. Profits are strong and the mortgage continues to be the bedrock on which this economy is built. Yes, we did take some losses in our subprime department last year. But those losses will be contained at 5%. Mark raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: (whispers) Hey Mark, this isn’t a Q and A... Mark juts his hand up even higher.

dialogues.speaker: OPTION ONE CEO
dialogues.text: Uh, yes... There’s a question?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Would you say it’s a possibility or a probability that subprime losses stop at 5%?!

dialogues.speaker: OPTION ONE CEO
dialogues.text: Well... I would say it’s a very strong probability. Mark raises his hand again. But his hand is in the shape ZERO.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Zero! There is a zero percent chance your subprime losses stop at
His phone rings.  102 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 79.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I have to take this! He gets up and leaves while answering his phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey honey... You’re just calling to say hi? Well that’s so sweet. How are the kids? Mark walks past Vennett, patting him on the shoulder. JAR flips him off and then looks to camera.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: The fucker really did this.

dialogues.speaker: CU OF EMAILS
dialogues.text: “Withdrawing money end of the month” “I trusted you. And you betrayed that trust. I am done wi Scion” “Will be severing ties with Scion next month” “When my two year period is over next month I withdraw al money from your fund” Mike Burry is looking at his emails at his desk. He looks pale and unhealthy. He now has only THREE EMPLOYEES -- th other desks have the abandoned look of people laid off quickly. Mike comes out and goes to the company white board. He wr the latest quarterly returns...-19.3%. On his way out, he stops at a ladder where his Assistant putting up Valentine’s decorations.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Can you come in early tomorrow? As you know, we also have big shorts in AIG and Countrywide, Frauddie Mac and I need to unload those positions to ensure we can afford the insurance premiums on our core mortgage short.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 79A.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Sure Dr. Burry. Mike starts to leave.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 80. ASSISTANT (CONT’D) Dr. Burry? What’s going to happen? If the investors withdraw, are we done?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Honestly? I don’t know. The bonds aren’t going down. They won’t move. It’s possible we are ina completely fraudulent system.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Or you’re wrong. Silence. ASSISTANT (CONT’D) I’m sorry. I just meant...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: That's okay Lewis. Yes, it’s possible I’m wrong. I don’t know how. But I guess when someone’s wrong they never know how. He leaves. A103 INT. BURRY’S BASEMENT - LATER A103

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: Michael sits behind drums and furiously plays double kick drum heavy metal drums to Pantera. Finally he breaks the sticks from playing so hard.

dialogues.speaker: AAAHHHHH
dialogues.text: We hear his wife from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Michael! Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yes honey!  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 81.

dialogues.speaker: MERRILL REP
dialogues.text: We can maybe sell you BBB level swaps at five-hundred basis points. Maybe. Ben and Charlie are testing the waters for a deal with th MERRILL REP at the Merrill Lynch Booth.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Five-hundred? You want us to pay a 5% premium on a swap? We paid 2% on the ones we got two months ago!

dialogues.speaker: MERRILL REP
dialogues.text: Good for you. That was two months ago. Trust me, you’re not gonna do any better anywhere else.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So you're pricing the swaps like the bond is going to collapse but the bond value has gone up? Really? How are you not in jail? Or at least-

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Charlie, let’s go. Thanks guys! We'll consider it. He takes Charlie firmly by the arm, marches him away.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: People are starting to wake up. Not enough for them to adjust the values on the bonds but enough to stop giving the swaps away. Cheap bets are over. The Rich Bear Rep passes them.

dialogues.speaker: BEAR REP
dialogues.text: Hey! It’s Brown hole!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fuck off!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You have to calm down.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 81a.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie in polo shirt and shorts is talking to a bookish bu pretty college friend who works at the SEC, EVIE, 30.

dialogues.speaker: EVIE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you got into finance Jamie. I always thought you'd... I don’t know. Be living off canned beans on your sailboat or mooching off older women at the yachtclub or something...

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Actually we’ve been investing in housing bonds and I wanted to ask, is the SEC worried about them? I mean, I know you can’t tell me specifics.. Just generally.  105 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 82.

dialogues.speaker: EVIE
dialogues.text: Oh we don’t investigate mortgage bonds. Truth is since we had our budget cut we don’t investigate much.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Really? Then why are you here? I thought-

dialogues.speaker: EVIE
dialogues.text: I’m not here for the SEC. I’m here on my own dime. (she leans in) I'm floating my resume to some big banks. How’s your brother by the way?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He’s good. (back to business) How are you floating your resume to big banks when you’re supposed to be the ones policing them?

dialogues.speaker: EVIE
dialogues.text: Grow up Jamie. 90% of the people at the SEC are just there to get better jobs. (she sees someone) Hey Doug! (then to Jamie) He’s at Goldman. She gets up and leaves. The guy she’s approaching grabs h

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Look everyone! It’s regulatory capture! He pulls Evie and himself into the pool. A whole group of bankers laugh while dance music plays. Jamie looks sicken

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie, Ben and Charlie are eating chopped salads.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Even Bear’s doubled their prices. And they keep calling us Brown Hole.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Don’t take it personally. You just don’t have the money or the reputation. 82A.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 83.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So I’m a broke loser with a bad reputation but don’t take it personally?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They're assholes. Let it go. (to Jamie) Did your friend from the SEC give any perspective?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The SEC isn’t even paying attention. Their budget has been gutted and they know zip about the housing market. It was actually depressing.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: People wanted small government, they got it. They eat for a beat, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... We need a deal that we can afford and they can’t refuse, right? What if we bet against the AA rated tranches of the CDOs? What’s cheaper than AA?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Come on Charlie. AA is so safe they barely even show up on the risk sheets for the banks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are they really though? We know if the bottom tranches fail at over 8% the double AA tranches are worth zero. We also know the ratings agencies and the SEC are asleep at the wheel. I bet those AAs are more like Bs. Jamie fishes some paper work out of his bag and points to some numbers.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Charlie’s right. The pay off is 200 to 1. But they don’t see it so they're charging pennies on the dollar to bet against the (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: AAs. With that kind of risk/reward we'd be fools not to do it.  106 107 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 84. Ben looks at the returns on AA swaps.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Just when I start thinking you guys are clowns... No one on the planet is betting against AA. The banks’11 think we’re high or having a stroke... And they’1l take every dime we have. Charlie LOOKS TO CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This is the thing we did that no one else did. Even Burry and Baum didn’t imagine the AAs could fail. MUSIC: A song with a beat like US v THEM by LCD SOUND SYS

dialogues.speaker: GOLDMAN REP
dialogues.text: I don’t understand, you want to bet against AA?

dialogues.speaker: BEAR REP
dialogues.text: Brother, I will sell you as much as you want. And you can shoot with us anytime you want.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIL REP
dialogues.text: What’s the angle here?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No angle. We want 10 million against a AA housing CDO.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMAN BROTHERS REP
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course yes. Wow. I thought this trip might be a waste of time. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN STANLEY REP
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes and yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they get AROUND A CORNER, Charlie AND Jamie SILENTLY CELEBRATE AND EVEN DANCE A BIT. But Ben tells them to coo it.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 85.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Do you even know what you just did?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we made the deal of our careers.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You just bet against the American economy. If we’re right it means people lose homes, jobs, retirement savings, pensions. These aren’t just numbers. For every point unemployment goes up, 40 thousand people die. Did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No... Jamie and Charlie look like kids who have been caught tea an old person.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We were just excited...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Just don’t fucking dance. Okay? He walks off. Exiting through double doors.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Home! I’11 call you when things get bad.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Alright Ben! Talk soon! (then to Jamie) Jesus. I didn’t know it could be that bad for the country. I guess this hasn’t really hit me yet. I just got scared. Are you scared?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’m always scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: Traditional Japanese string version of something l LIONEL RITCHIE’S EASY  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 85A. A tranquil waterfall out of plate glass windows. Jared wa in with Mark and his team.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: Alight Mark Baum from Frontpoint Partners... You’re nervous you and your swaps are being played? Now you get to meet who you’re betting against. Try not to get too righteous and listen for once.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 86.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. So who is this guy? FLASH CUT: Mark sits at a table. His dining partner is MR CHAU (50), Chinese-American, an expensive suit.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: I'm a CDO manager. At Harding Advisors.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I didn't know there was anything to manage.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: We select the securities that go into the CDO portfolio, and monitor the assets. I do most of Merrill Lynch's CDOs. Mark glances through hibachi steam to see Jared... raisin his beer. Meet your counter-party. Meet the sucker.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: And you represent investors or the bank?

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: The investors.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: But Merrill's only going to send you buyers if you put Merrill's bonds in your CDOs.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: Let’s just say Merrill and I have a good relationship. Mark can't tell if Mr. Chau is being naive or just arch.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 87.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Are you worried about rising default rates?

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: I assume no risk for these products myself.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight. The bank calls you up. Gives you bonds they want to sell. Gives you the clients. Gives you the money to run your business. Gives you fat fees for doing so. But you represent the investors? Mr. Chau finally chuckles -- he’s actually being defiant.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: Yes. But my office is not in the Merrill Lynch building. We’re in New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: 20 minutes away.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: 5 if we use a helicopter. MOMENTS LATER: Vinny, Jared and Danny nervously watch Mar huddle with Mr. Chau. Mark’s animated, speaking too loudl

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Say that again! Say that again!

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Your boss is about to explode.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: No. He’s too curious to explode. Ignoring his food, Mark scribbles furiously on a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: CDO A has parts of CDO B and CDO B has parts CDO A, but then both get put inside CDO C?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 88-89.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: That one's called a CDO Squared. And then there are CDOs made up of the opposite side of the bet you made with your swaps. We call them synthetic CDOs.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: “Synthetic CDOs?” LATER: Mark’s completely disheveled now, tie off. Mr. Cha as decorous as ever, enjoying his dessert. Another paper napkin slaps the counter.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. This is a pool of, say, 50 million in subprime loans. How much money could be out there betting on it through these synthetic CDOs and swaps?! Right now?! Tonight?!

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: A billion dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What?! Mr. Chau shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much bigger is the market for insuring mortgage bonds than actual mortgages?!

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: Twenty times? We FREEZE on his disoriented expression.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If the flawed mortgage bonds that Michael Burry discovered were the match. And the CDOs Jamie and Charlie bet against were the kerosene soaked rags... Then the synthetic CDO was the atomic bomb with a drunk President holding his finger over the button. At that moment Mark Baum realized the whole world economy might collapse. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 88-89A.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I’m sure you’re wondering one thing: what the hell is a “synthetic CDO?” Well here is Dr. Richard Thaler, the father of Behavioral Economics and international pop star Selena Gomez to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SELENA GOMEZ sits at a black jack table with a giant stac chips. She wins another hand and rakes in more chips from PROFESSIONAL DEALER. A crowd cheers her on around the tab

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: She can’t lose! That’s seven hands in a row!

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: So here’s how a synthetic CDO works. Let’s say I make a bet of 10 million on a black jack hand...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: 10 million because this hand represents a simple mortgage bond. She is dealt a Jack and an 8 by the dealer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Selena is showing 18 and the dealer is showing a seven. So the odds are very much in Selena’s favor. 87% to be exact. Which are like the great odds most perceived the housing market to have.

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: Did you really create a whole field of economic study?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: Well is was inspired by the great work of others, but yes.

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: I have 30 million twitter followers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: I have 30,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH +e % He HHH HH OF +e %

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: (Trying to be encouraging) That’s not bad. (back to the explanation) So my odds are great. And I am ona winning streak. Everyone else here wants in on this. I can’t lose, right?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: We have done countless studies that show that people often make this error in their thinking. If something is happening-- like Selena winning seven hands in a row

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: Or the housing market going up for seven years straight...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: Exactly. They think it will go on forever. It’s called extrapolation bias. People see something happening and they extrapolate that it will continue to happen.

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: So the people who are watching and think I can’t lose will make a side bet which is the first CDO. We see A WOMAN IN GLASSES standing behind SELENA. She tur to a BUSINESS MAN.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN IN GLASSES
dialogues.text: Wow. I love Selena Gomez. And she’s won seven in a row with a seven showing for the dealer. I bet you 50 million she wins and I'll give you three to one odds.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: 3 to 1 odds? Okay, I’1l take that bet.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: Then someone behind him decides to bet on their bet with someone else. That's synthetic CDO number two. There’s a GUY IN A WARRIORS GAME JERSEY talking to a AN O WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HHH HF FF HH OF HHH HH + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: GUY IN GAME JERSEY
dialogues.text: Hey I bet you 200 million that lady in the glasses wins that bet.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: She probably will win, she always does, so I want a great pay off.

dialogues.speaker: GUY IN GAME JERSEY
dialogues.text: How about 20 to 1?

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: And this goes on and on and on and on.... With more and more CDOs betting on the bet on the bet on the bet...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: This happens all the time. In the stock market. In sports. In basketball, they call the Hot Hand fallacy. A player hits 3 shots ina row and everyone thinks he is definitely going to make that 4th one. We know, from a lot of statistical evidence, that there is no such thing as hot hands, but people refuse to accept that.

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: People are cray cray.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: I don’t know what that means. We see a LONG LINE OF PAIRS OF PEOPLE making bets of increasing value and complexity that stretches behind Sel Thaler at the table down the hall and around the corner and out of the doors of the casino.

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: And then the dealer plays out his hand. The dealer turns over a 3, giving him 10 and then turns o a King. DEALER WINS. SELENA GOMEZ (CONT’D) No! How could I lose!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is then a long chain reaction of winners and losers reactions.

dialogues.speaker: LONG CHAIN OF BETTERS
dialogues.text: Shit! Pay up! Crap! Wait, I lost? I want my money! How could Selena lose! Nooo!!!

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: They all should have known the odds they could lose. But they got overconfident. And because of the synthetic CDOs and all the bets on bets on bets... The one loss becomes thousands of losses.

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: And those losers? Pension funds, insurance companies. City governments all over the world. Crazy shit right?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THALER
dialogues.text: Not crazy, just human. The crazy part is assuming people will act logically all the time.

dialogues.speaker: SELENA GOMEZ
dialogues.text: Translation: crazy shit. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e HH FH FH HF +e * HF + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNFREEZE BAUM AND MR. CHAU. All Mark can think to do is s and collect his things.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I have to go. Honestly I feel a bit sick. Be careful, Mr. Chau. You'll make a lot of money... until you don't.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CHAU
dialogues.text: You think I’m a parasite Mr. Baum? But apparently, society values me very much. (a beat) In fact, let's do this... I'll tell you what I'm worth, you tell me what you're worth. Mark looks straight in the face of everything he hates.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I don't think you're a parasite, Mr Chau. (sincere) I think you're an idiot. Mark walks away and past Jared and the guys.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Short everything that guy has touched. (he walks away) I want half a billion more in swaps!

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: The collateral calls could bankrupt you.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yup!  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 92.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. CAESAR’S PALACE - THE NEXT MORNING 111 SLO MO: Hungover and broke people straggle out of the hot in the bright morning Vegas sun dragging luggage. They ge into valet’d cars and cabs. Charlie and Jamie exit and jump into a Mercedes SUV. They looked vaguely ashamed and Charlie looks freaked. Mr. Chau walks out with a smile on his face, designer lug and enters a stretch limo. A short moment later Mark, Porter, Danny and Vinny walk o Mark looks particularly far away and haggard. Three of the Bear Stearns firing range guys leave with tw BEDRAGGLED PARTY GIRLS. They’re still drunk. They get ina Humvee Limo. And last, we see Evie, from the SEC and the Goldman Sachs guy, Doug, leaving together. They kiss and then he gets i Range Rover and she gets in a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark struggles to pull his bag out of a taxi's trunk.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Did you eat on the plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baum’s are in an elegant and isolated seating area in Cynthia’s upscale clothing boutique.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What's wrong? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Things are worse than I thought. I honestly think the economy might collapse.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. (then) And we could end up making a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Define fortune.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: The fund could make half a billion, Cynthia. Maybe a lot more. She had no idea. A SALES CLERK approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SALES CLERK
dialogues.text: Ms. Baum should I- ?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Not now Paula. You’re my manager. I trust you. They lower their voices, lean closer.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A half a billion on one trade?! How is that even possible?!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Group think. Fraud. Legalized corruption. Stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You've been saying the whole system is broken for years Mark. Why are you shocked?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: It’s all so much uglier and more twisted than I ever imagined. And I’m a banker. I’m a part of this horrible world. A silence between them. Cynthia refuses to break it.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: And I keep thinking about my brother. About Paul. And how he.. When he...

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When Paul took his own life.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: ...-We can talk about it later. You're at your store-

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Mark. 93A.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Before... my brother... committed suicide... when he told me he was having bad thoughts... My first response was... to offer him some money. My brother was in pain. Real pain. And I offered him... money.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You tried to help. There’s no perfect way...

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: All this greed in the world. Maybe I’m not so above it. Maybe I’m part of it. And it’s changed me. Changed me into a person who’s not able to reach out to someone who’s hurting without money being a part of it. (beat) Does it bother you that I feel that way?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: No. You can’t name a scenario for how I could have helped him that doesn’t play in my head every day. But it bothers me that you’re so certain you’re right. Because you're not. His silence means yes.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You love to know more than other people. To be the virtuous one. You always have Mark. As though you’re untainted and we’re al the filthy masses clawing at Noah’s arch. But the truth is: you're a banker. A banker who makes more than he should. A banker who had a terrible thing happen to a family member. And now you’re about to make a lot of money from another terrible thing. And even you can’t find a way to make that virtuous. Because it’s not. It’s just life. And sometimes it hurts and it’s sad and it’s scary. So stop trying to fix the world and just feel the feelings like all of us. Because they’re there. (MORE )
BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 94a.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when you act like they’re not it makes me want to scream. Mark starts to break.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: (tears up) Paul was always there for me... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 95.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His face was so smashed we couldn’t even have an open casket... He just dropped the phone...

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: He couldn’t hear anyone. That’s why he’s dead... There’s nothing you could have done. They both sit there holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing. INT. WAITING AREA —- PEDIATRIC PSYCH CENTER - DUSK 114 Mike's son Nicholas plays alone, talking to himself about different parts of a BACKHOE LOADER. Stabilizer legs...bucket...atriculated arm... Mike enters. His Wife's been waiting, annoyed, gestures t her watch. Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m late. Everything’s falling apart at work. People want to remove their money from the fund. I don’t know what to do. His wife doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong. Is Nicholas okay?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE'S WIFE
dialogues.text: (upset, quiet) They think it's Asperger's Syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No. What? What...what's the symptomology?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike has a stack of books: Attwood's The Complete Guide t Asperger's, Baron-Cohen's Mindblindness, etc. Sceptical, he chooses A Parent's Guide and reads...  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 96.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "The first sign a child is on the Autism spectrum is often a hobby. It will be one that is solitary and idiosyncratic, and it will completely obsess the child." Mike's surprised, this actually resonates. JUMP CUTS: A dizzying whirl of TEXT PASSAGES fly at us...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ",..few real peer- to-peer relationships...less eye contact... .--ability to quickly absorb complex systems ...love of computers... math... good with numbers Mike stops reading. Sweating. Thunderstruck. A strange truth settles over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike has sought counsel from a MED SCHOOL FRIEND, a psych ward doctor currently self-medicating on a joint.

dialogues.speaker: MED SCHOOL FRIEND
dialogues.text: This is good, a diagnosis like this, as an adult, it's all upside. You don’t have to feel like there’s something wrong with you anymore. Now you know. Mystery is solved.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What's the upside of having Aspergers?

dialogues.speaker: MED SCHOOL FRIEND
dialogues.text: C'mon, Burry, who else but an Aspie actually reads entire bond prospectuses?! Your whole life your brain's told you one thing and society another. Now, you get to stop listening to society. Stop caring what we think! Don't you get it? We're normal. We can't keep up. CLOSE on Mike, taken with the idea, and its implications.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "To All Investors"  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 97. MUSIC: A heavy metal song like METALLICA’S EYE OF THE BEHOLDER fades in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike types an email. He is alone in the office with empty desks outside.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "As you may know, our agreement allows me to take extraordinary measures when markets aren't functioning properly. I currently have reason to believe the mortgage bond market is fraudulent. So in order to protect investors from this fraudulent market I've decided to restrict investors’ withdrawals until further notice. Sincerely. Dr. Michael Burry." Mike breathes deep, and hits SEND. He sits listening to the quiet hum of office outside his door. The distant highway. A very long beat. Slowly at first, isolated, then gathering like an angry storm, the office PHONES begin to RING and his email box begins to ding. One email stands out: From Lawrence Fields. The subject: SUING.

dialogues.speaker: OVER BLACK WE SEE THE QUOTE
dialogues.text: “Everyone, deep in their hearts, is waiting for the end o the world to come.” - Haruki Murakami, 1084 We DISSOLVE to TV Channels flipping from one to the next. 1) SOME SORT OF FLUFFY POP ENTERTAINMENT, a sitcom, game show, reality show.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 98. 2) BARRY BONDS defends himself in a press conference. 3) Footage celebrating Lance Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is the one flipping through the TV channels. Jami on his lap top. They’re restless, tense and killing time. April 2, 2007 The Crash Begins

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Will you stop changing the channels? You’re driving me crazy. Just put the business news on. Charlie turns the channel to business news.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fine. Jamie stops and watches while Charlie rolls over on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: See what?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: On the crawl! He grabs the remote and rewinds and freezes the TV. On th crawl at the bottom of the financial news show we see:  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 99. Nation's second-largest mortgage lender bankrupt.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s starting.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to call my Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinny, Danny and Porter watch Kathy, thin again, yelling Mark in the Conference Room. ON A WALL TV: The FED CHAIRMAN is speaking to Congress. The Dow is down 283 points.

dialogues.speaker: BERNANKE, (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: ...We believe the effect of the troubles in the subprime sector on the broader housing market will likely be limited, and we do not expect significant spillovers from the subprime market to the rest of the economy--

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Turn off all the financial news. They're in crazy land. We’re trying to stay in reality. An assistant turns off all the TVs in the office. Danny Moses, on the phone yells over to Vinny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY MOSES
dialogues.text: Duetsche says the CDOs still haven’t lost any value!

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: The banks are holding the value til they can dump their position... They know now. The DOOR opens. Kathy and her minions storm off... and ou Mark emerges beaten, yet hardened. VINNY (CONT’D) Well?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Kathy wants us to dump our shorts.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 100.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: What else is new?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: She says Morgan Stanley will buy them.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What?! Holy shit. Vinny’s right, they need our shorts. They know.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: The whole time we were wondering who's on the other side of this bet and it’s the big banks themselves. They believed their own bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What’d you tell Kathy?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I told her we're not selling shit. If Morgan needs to lose half a billion cause they screwed up it’s not my problem.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: So now what’d we do?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is getting off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You need to understand, mom. This isn’t just a banking thing. It’s going to affect real people. All over the world. Like an enormous tsunami hitting the global economy all at once... Yeah, OK. I love you, too. He hangs up and turns to Jamie who’s at his computer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She told me I should go on lithium. Jamie shows him an email on his computer.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 100A.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Check it out - from Bear Stearns. They claim the CDOs still haven't moved.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 101.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s insane. They’re crooks. Just look at the ABX: those CDOs should be at zero! You know what they’re doing, right? They’re selling off their worthless CDOs so they don’t take the loses. That’s fraud. Ona massive scale. (looks panicked) Jeez, I can’t catch my breath. I think I’m having a panic attack.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We've got to tell someone. The whole world has no idea what’s about to hit them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Who? The SEC is useless. The ratings agencies are in on it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Let’s go to the press. This is a giant story. Who wouldn’t publish it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Jamie just explained the situation to CASEY, their college friend, and the junior finance reporter.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: So what am I supposed to do? Write a piece called “We’re all fucked?”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes! That's a perfect title.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Casey, right now every bank in town is unloading these shit bonds on unsuspecting customers. They won't devalue them until they unload them. This is the biggest fraud in banking history.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: It took years to build my relationships on Wall Street! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CASEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No bank or ratings agency is going to confirm a story like this just because two guys in a garage-band hedge-fund thinks it’s the apocalypse.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be a dick Casey. We didn’t say “apocalypse.”  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 102.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wow. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (tries again) Look, these banks bought most of the government. They bought the ratings agencies. There’s no one left but you. This story is why journalism exists. If someone like you blows this off because they’re worried about access to the banks this country is fucked.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Nice speech Kev. You sound like Oliver Stone. (he gets up) Look, I’ve got work to do. So thanks for stopping by.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Stop saying Wow. (back to Casey) I thought you were for real Casey. I really did.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well you try being “for real” with a three year old and a wife who's getting her Master's degree. I’m not burning my reputation on your wild hunch.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wow. He’s holding the door for them. They exit.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Thanks for stopping by. Totally fucking awesome to see you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Disgusting. He won’t do his job because he wants to keep access to the banks to keep doing the job he won't do?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I just had a horrible thought.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm already juggling five or six horrible thoughts. Don’t tell me. 102A.  124 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 103.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: If Bear Stearn is freezing the value of the CDOs it must mean they own tons of them. (a breath) They could go under. And we bought 80% of our swaps at Bear. We’d lose everything.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Stop it. Bear Stearns has been around for a hundred years. They’re not going under.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We have to at least consider the possibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is at his desk. The headline on the site he’s on is: Bear Stearns liquidates mortgage backed securities hedge funds. Losses at 3.6 Billion. The office is completely empty save two LAWYERS who are wheeling files out on a hand cart. Michael is on the phon hearing a voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (SOT)
dialogues.text: You've reached Lucy Thalia at Goldman Sachs. I’m not available- He hangs up. July 31, 2007

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: That should do it Dr. Burry.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: If you need any files from 2005-

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: Mr. Field’s suit is very specific to files from the past year.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY
dialogues.text: Well then tell Lawrence I said hi. Burry’s PHONE rings. The caller ID is Thalia/Private.  Static. BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 104.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (answering) You can't get back to me for a whole week?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY THALIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Mike. Goldman had a systems failure. I lost a ton of messages.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: B of A said they had a power outage. And Morgan Stanley said their server crashed.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY THALIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Huh. That's weird.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I would call it improbable. Where do you have our position marked?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY THALIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It could be the same, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Can you explain that to me? How's the value of an insurance contract in no way affected by the demise of the thing it insures?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY THALIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They're independent markets. They’re not always correlated. I know it sounds odd but these are very complicated products.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: They are correlated, and I can prove it.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY THALIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You'd never claim they're uncorrelated on a hard line -- those are recorded bank records -- but you'll say it on your cell phone.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 104A.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 105.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY THALIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mike, I need to call you right back. She clicks off. Mike hangs up. The phone RINGS again almost immediately. Goldman.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (answers) I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: A DIFFERENT VOICE
dialogues.text: Dr. Burry?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DEEB
dialogues.text: Deeb Winston, Goldman Sachs. Listen, I've been reviewing your position. I wanted to discuss your marks, make sure they're fair. Mike realizes what's happened.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I think you mean you've secured a net short position yourselves so you're free to mark my swaps accurately for once. Because it's now in your interest to do so. Static.

dialogues.speaker: DEEB
dialogues.text: I'm not sure what you want me to say.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Mike hangs up. There. See. Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trading desk is hopping. We see someone on their comp on Bloomberg.com. The story: Countrywide Financial Warns “Difficult Conditions.” The Dow is down 325 points  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 106. Mark has a phone full of blinking red lights, about to pu up a call, as soon Danny finishes prepping him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Subprime bonds went off a cliff. Rumor is default numbers are huge.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Who got the remittance data early? I bet it’s Goldman. Mark punches a blinking light.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jared, it's chaos over here. Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jared enters a bathroom, pushes a BANKER OUT THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT
dialogues.text: The gods have spoken. No one’s buying CDO or mortgage bonds anymore. (To the guy he’s pushing out) Sorry, important call! (then back to Mark) Our secret's out. Swaps are now the most valuable product on the street. And I heard from someone who heard from someone that Bennie Leibman over at Morgan just took some heavy losses in Morgan's bond department. Your ship might be taking on water... It might be time to grab a life jacket. Mark hangs up. Everyone's looking his direction.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: The market's turned. A long, weird beat. No one speaks. No one celebrates. For good reason...

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Kathy's office is looking for you.  127 128 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark strides for a corner office. A young woman passes in tears, carrying a personal effects box and crying, newly fired. INT. MORGAN STANLEY - KATHY TAO’S OFFICE - DAY 128 A BREAST-PUMP on a credenza. Mark’s waiting on Kathy. Considering her Spartan office, realizes she has no personal effects, save the pump. Kathy Tao enters, frazzled, scared.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming so quickly, Mark. I’m sure you’ve been hearing rumblings about some losses Morgan has suffered. He nods. She sits.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: What? He points to the breast pump.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks. I just wanted you to know that yes, Morgan has suffered some losses but our liquidity is strong and there’s no cause for concern.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What about Bennie Leibman? Is he concerned. Word on the street is he took some heavy losses. Half beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We know each other too well Kathy. How bad is it?  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 107A.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: Okay. Two years ago, Bennie Leibman in Morgan’s bond department also started shorting subprime housing. 2 billion in triple B’s.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Bennie's smarter than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: Not smart enough. The premiums on the swaps ate into his desk's profit. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To cover his triple B shorts he sold a lot of A and double A swaps as protection. A lot. He believed there was no way they could be affected.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Tell me Morgan Stanley doesn’t hold those contracts. Silence. They held them. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s your exposure. 3 billion? Don’t tell me it’s over 4.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: I can’t answer that. And I’m not sure there’s even a definitive answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Kathy, you bring me in here to say everything’s fine and you don’t mention Bennie’s losses. You’1l have to pardon me if I don’t believe a word you’re saying right now.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: Our long exposure is somewhere between 12 and 16 billion.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ... Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: He kept saying defaults over 8 percent were impossible. There'd be a million homeless.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: And how is that a reason it can’t happen?!

dialogues.speaker: KATHY TAO
dialogues.text: No one thought... Please don’t do this Mark. Like it or not you're part of Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Kathy, given Morgan's leverage, what are you doing to prevent a run on this bank? We see she’s not just stunned, she’s terrified. 108A.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a window table, Mark and Vinny sit across from Porter Danny.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: But we have nothing to do with Morgan Stanley!

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Tell the bankruptcy court. Morgan fails, our accounts go on their balance sheet.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That’s crazy. Morgan makes the sucker’s bet and we pay their gambling debts. Mark’s brooding dangerously.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You're saying, we could do everything right, disciplined, smart, and still go broke?

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Short the bank stocks. Then we wait.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Or... we sell our swaps, when the market opens. We get our bonuses and our investors get their profits. We'd get 30 cents on the dollar. Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They're worth three times that.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: If Morgan goes under it won't matter.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
