dialogues.text: Forget it. I'm not giving away lifeboats.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 110.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Mark, don’t play a game of chicken on this one.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Drop it! Christ, Vin. We sell when I say we sell. Don't pussy out on me!

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: I get that this is what you've dreamed about but we have a fiduciary responsibility to-

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: No. No we don’t. No one is being responsible. So fuck responsibility. We’re going to shove the knife in to the hilt and make these assholes at the big banks-—

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: (approaching) --you boys want--

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: --we're talking! Excuse us. The Waitress is wounded. Goes. A brutal beat. No one can at Mark.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quiet) I’1ll say when we sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie is walking down the street on his cell. August 3, 2007

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: So not only do two mortgage hedge funds backed by Bear Stearns go belly up but now there’s a class action law suit against Bear.  131 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 110A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SPIN CLASS IS IN PROGRESS WITH LOUD MUSIC PLAYING and 2 people on bikes. A sweaty Charlie is standing off to the on his cell.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (yelling over the music) Holy shit! Bear Stearns could really collapse?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know if Bear will collapse. But there’s a risk they might. And it’s a risk we shouldn’t take.  132 133 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 lll.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How the hell do we sell these swaps!? I just realized we bought them but we don’t know how to sell them.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We'll have to get Ben to do it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s on vacation with his wife’s family in England! The Spin Class instructor turns to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Hey brother! Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Mike's good eye: he's scanning his monitors. January 14, 2008 He hovers over his terminal, worried. The numbers are not good. We see default rates above 12%, Dow down 420 points etc. He picks up the phone and dials a number by heart.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It's Dr. Burry. Looks like the collapse in the financial sector is imminent. Let's start to unwind my position. It's 1.3 Billion. We hear disappointment in Mike's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been cleared out, even Mike's Assistant is gone. The light goes off in his inner office. Leaving, Mike stops off at his WHITE BOARD, erases -19.3% with his palm and starts to write +... He stops, turns and considers the room full of abandoned desks, just a telephone on each, all of them silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A southern England old world pub on a wet street in a sma country town.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve got almost no cell phone or wifi reception and I’m trying to sell 200 million dollars worth of securities. And yes, this pub smells like wet sheep.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You can do this Ben ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben has his Bloomberg terminal set up at a table, wears a fancy headset, rolls calls in sweatpants.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: This is The Brownfield Fund... I'm trying to sell credit default swaps...20 double A tranches of CDOs...Absolutely, they're all complete shit... Face value is 205 million dollars. The PROPRIETRESS and THREE OLD ENGLISH MEN AT THE BAR pre not to listen to the strangest conversation they've ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, we're looking for at least 100 million.

dialogues.speaker: PUB-GOER
dialogues.text: 100 million! Hey laddy, are you a drug dealer or a banker?! If you’re a banker fuck off! Everyone laughs in the pub. Now they’re openly watching.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Just give me your best number.

dialogues.speaker: PUB-GOER
dialogues.text: Have em throw in a million for me!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Look, if you don’t want this deal then hang up... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (they don’t hang up) That’s what I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Jamie stand around Charlie’s SPEAKER PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Eighty million. Okay. That's good.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Eighty's great, Ben. Thank you. Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Most of it went to UBS. You're very lucky. The largest bank in France froze customers money market accounts today. This thing's hitting Europe. I hope I can get home...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You will. Call us when you land.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey Ben, I’m just wondering, why did you do this with us? I mean, you didn’t have to.... and thanks. But why?

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Because I like you guys.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (thrown ) Wow. You do? That’s so cool... Okay... Bye Ben. Hello? Oh. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eighty million in 6 months. From just 110 thousand 4 years ago. That's not bad.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m done. No more.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 113A.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, me too. (half beat) But we have to short Bear Stearns.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You damn straight. (realizing) Oh, crap, where are we gonna put the money we made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Elegant. A well-heeled crowd of 200 INVESTORS. March 14, 2008

dialogues.speaker: JARED VENNETT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As the housing markets and banks continued to hemorrhage only one of the big shorts refused to sell: Mark Baum. So it was beyond perfect when he was asked to speak at a conference opposite Bruce Miller, a famous bullish investor. After he and Mark had their debate, Alan Greenspan, one of the architects of the whole crisis was scheduled to speak. Everyone in Mark’s office showed up and even invited friends.... This was Ali versus Foreman of the financial world... The realist versus the fools. If it seems almost too perfect, trust me, this happened. And it was beautiful. A podium waits for Greenspan. Beside it are 3 chairs with HOST, BRUCE MILLER, ruddy and confident and a sloppily- dressed Mark Baum. Vinny's in the front row.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE MILLER, (THE BULL)
dialogues.text: As some of you may know, Bear Stearns just received a loan from JP Morgan. We'll see how the market reacts, but I think that lays to rest concerns about the bank's health.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOST
dialogues.text: I take it you have no plans to sell your 200 million in Bear stock?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE MILLER
dialogues.text: When we're done here, I'll probably buy more.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOST
dialogues.text: For the opposing view, Mr. Baum.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I gotta stand for this.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 114A. Wholly uninvited, Mark takes his mic to the podium.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 115.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, hi, so my firm's thesis is simple: Wall Street took a good idea, Lewis Ranieri’s Mortgage Bond and turned it into an atomic bomb of fraud and stupidity that is on it’s way to decimating the world economy.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE MILLER
dialogues.text: How do you really feel? The crowd laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I’m glad you still have a sense of humor. I wouldn't if I were you. (back to the crowd) Now, anyone who knows me knows I have no problem telling someone they're wrong. Hell, it’s my passion. (beat) Well for the first time in my life, it’s not so enjoyable. Arriving late, Porter slips in the last row behind Danny.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (whispers) Bear Stearns issued a press release denying rumors of liquidity problems.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (whispers) They said they had liquidity?! That always means they don’t.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: We're living in an era of fraud in America. Not just in banking. But in government, education, food, religion, journalism, prisons, baseball... Somehow, American values became fuck it, let’s grab what we can for now and the hell with tomorrow. Danny gets a quote, curses, types, Here we go! Bear at 47

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what bothers me isn’t that fraud is “not nice” or “mean.” It’s that for fifteen thousand years fraud and short sighted thinking has never, ever worked. Not once. How the hell did we all forget that? Vinny gets a text...Bear at 35 last!

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought we were all better than this... I really did. And the fact that we’re not doesn’t make me feel superior and right... It makes me feel sad... In the back, a man hurries out holding on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And as fun as it is seeing pompous dumb Wall Streeters be wildly wrong, (turns to the Bull) and you are wrong sir. (back to his wrap up) I just know that at the end of the day regular people are going to pay for all of this. Because they always, always do. Danny's just typed Bear at 29 last!!! as he hears this.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's my two cents. Thank you. Mark pats Bruce Miller on the back as he takes his seat.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOST
dialogues.text: Does our bull have a response?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE MILLER
dialogues.text: Only that in the history of Wall Street, no investment bank has ever failed except when caught in criminal activities. So I stand by my Bear Stearns optimism. A YOUNG BANKER stands, unwilling to wait for the Q & A.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER
dialogues.text: Mr. Miller! Sorry. Quick Question. (re: his Blackberry) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 138 139 140 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 117.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BANKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: From the time you guys started talking, Bear Stearns stock has fallen more than 38 percent. Would you buy more now?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE MILLER
dialogues.text: (unsure) Sure. Yeah. I'd buy more. Why not? Awkward silence. Mark whispers into his mic...

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Boom. Mark watches the whole room scramble for the aisles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PR PERSON leads ALAN GREENSPAN (never fully seen) and h ENTOURAGE toward an auditorium door.

dialogues.speaker: PR PERSON
dialogues.text: This way Mr. Greenspan. We are so honored to have you here today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PR Person leads Greenspan and entourage in up front. THERE ARE ONLY SIX AUDIENCE MEMBERS in the vast hall.

dialogues.speaker: PR PERSON
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty. The SCROLL is dead. Suddenly, it flickers and kicks to life as if re-booted. The first message says it all... Lehman bankruptcy leaves country in turmoil.  141 142 143 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful day. Charlie stands on a bench watching LEHMA EMPLOYEES with effects boxes exit through a PRESS gauntle September 15, 2008 Jamie ends a call below him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: That was Ben . The Dow has dropped 1800 points in the last three days. He thinks the price of gold could go higher than the Dow. Up is now officially down. Charlie is still watching the chaos at Lehman.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I want to see inside.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His box already in a taxi, a LEHMAN GUY looks from Jamie Charlie’s expectant faces to the building. Fuck it. The Guy takes off his ID tag and hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Which floor's fixed income?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinny is on the phone. Danny and Porter work quietly if feverishly at their desks that are covered in screens.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Mark! Answer your phone! We have to sell! This whole thing’s blowing up!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Prices are moving... I can't get a fix! Danny's panicked.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 119.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have like 70 positions...I can't...I don't know what's happening to anything! Morgan's lost a third of it's value. Vinny and Porter exchange a worried glance.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Is it a run?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Danny, is there a run on Morgan Stanley?!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know! Danny squints at his screens; something's wrong with his vision. He's soaking wet. Looks down at his chest.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I'm having a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: No, you're not. He's extremely pale but doesn't walk from the desk, tries regulate his breathing as Porter and Vinny watch.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're not having a heart attack. (no response) You're not having a heart attack. (no response) You're not having a heart attack. Danny looks as if he can't hear.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, maybe you are. Vinny picks up the phone to call 911.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Hello, we need an ambulance, now!  144 145 146 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DIMINUTIVE EXEC is in the flow of departing Employees.

dialogues.speaker: DIMINUTIVE EXEC
dialogues.text: Go straight to your transportation! Do not talk to the press! Go straight to your transportation! Do not talk to the press! Jamie holds up the pass for a Guard, who hurriedly waves and Charlie through the turnstile, like two diplomats slipping back in the embassy as Saigon falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abandoned. A few EMPLOYEES pack. Loose paper's everywhere Charlie and Jamie walk through the destruction: plundered desks; emptied picture frames; sad tchotkes. On one desk, someone's made a pyramid of Red Bull cans. On one wall, someone's painted a huge...LEH: 0.00.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This isn't how I pictured it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What'd you think we'd find? Charlie considers this question a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The grown-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUSINESS CROWD passes. On the church steps, Danny is now okay. He, Vinny and Por watch the crowd, rushing past, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah... I think so. It’s embarrassing. I really thought I was having a heart attack.  147

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Let’s go to dinner tonight. I hear there’s a great new Cuban joint in the lower east side.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Really? I’d like that. Vinny paces. His Blackberry RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: Mark, finally! (answering) Hey, it's a bloodbath up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits at a table with his laptop and a coffee, shell shocked staring off into the building around him. Vinny's on Mark's cell phone speaker.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Word's out. Morgan's stock has lost half its value. Down to 23.10. Clients are wanting to talk to you about pulling their money. (then) It's now or never. We gotta sell Mark. (silence) Hello? (nothing) Mark?!

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. CLOSE on MARK. He's staring at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: At least tell me what you're thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I met my wife on Match.com. My profile said, quote, I am a medical student with only one eye, an awkward social manner, and $145,000 in student loans, end quote. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: A150
dialogues.text: 150 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 122.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL BURRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She wrote back: you're just what I've been looking for. She meant honest. So, let me be honest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bare feet on corporate carpet.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--making money is not like I thought it would be. Mike's at the Assistant's Desk sorting through a stack of mail. He's also listening to the VOICE MAIL on the phone' speaker, erasing most messages after they start.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE MAIL MESSAGE
dialogues.text: Oh, Mike, this is Kerry Mann down at Camelot Capital. Listen, we see you're jumping back in the equities market in a big way. In this environment, we're not sure that's a wise-- He hits ERASE. And keeps sorting.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This business kills the part of life that is essential: the part that has nothing to do with business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burry’s FORMER ASSISTANT is stocking Red Bulls in a convenience store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood Baum toured with the real estate agent i now covered with foreclosure signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two dozen others, Marlene and the Younger Agent are taking a seminar, “You Can Be a Real Estate Millionaire”.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 122A.

dialogues.speaker: SEMINAR LEADER
dialogues.text: (again) The housing crisis represents the greatest financial opportunity of your lifetime!  151 152 153 154 155 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 123.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man with the Tattooed Head comes out of the store and hurries to his CAR, carrying food. When he gets in, we se his child, wife and their stuff. They now live in the car

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For the past two years my insides have felt like they’re eating themselves. All the people I respected won’t talk to me anymore except through lawyers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large JOB FAIR. Maroon waits in a long line for his turn with an ADVISOR, of many in a row of folding tables. He looks over to see friend, Black, in another line. Nods. Hey. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: People want an authority to tell them how to value things. But they chose this authority not based on facts or results. They chose it because it seems authoritative and familiar. And I am not and never have been... “familiar.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The West African Cab Driver that drove Mark looks at his 401K. It says -43,540 dollars. Leaving only 46k.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike types the email we've been hearing in VO throughout.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So, I've come to the sullen realization that I must close down the fund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the night Mike erased the WHITE BOARD in the empty office. This time, we watch him write his fund's growth...+489%.  156 157 BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 124.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am writing this to inform you that earlier today I sold off all positions for Scion Fund. He circles it. Then walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inscrutable, Jared Vennett considers a BONUS LETTER on hi desk. He talks to camera.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: (to camera) I can’t really say it to anyone else, but I’1ll say it to you: I was right. I took a rash of shit for the past two years but I was right. His bonus for 2008 is $47,000,000.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey I never said I was the hero of this story. He kisses the check.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can feel you judging me... Remember, I made this bank 20 billion. My two bosses lost 30 billion and still got fifty million in bonuses. You didn’t see that on your news did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark as before, quiet, talking to Vinny via cell phone. MUSIC: A piano piece like THE TWINS by MAX RICHTER fades slowly

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mark!? At least tell me what you're thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Paulson and Bernanke just left the White House. There's going to be a bailout. Mark’s voice is full of masked emotion, quiet, resigned.  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 124A.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're serious?!  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 125.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah... The whole time we were wondering how the big banks could be so stupid... They didn’t care. They knew the tax payers had to bail em out.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Those fuckers. (and then) At least we’ll see some of them go to jail. And they’re going to have to break up the banks.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I don’t know Vinny. I bet in a few years we'll be doing what people always do when the economy goes south: blaming immigrants and poor people.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But Mark was wrong. In the years that followed 100’s of bankers and rating’s agency executives went to jail. The SEC was completely overhauled.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Congress had no choice but to break up the big banks and regulate the mortgage and derivatives industries. (Beat) Just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The banks took the money the American people gave them and used it to lobby the Congress to kill big reform. And then America blamed immigrants and poor people. And this time... even teachers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when all was said and done, only one single banker went to jail. PICTURE OF THE ONE BANKER WHO WENT TO JAIL.

dialogues.speaker: JARED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This poor schmuck. Kareem Serageldin from Credit Suisse. He hid a few billion in mortgage bond losses. Something most of the big banks do on a good day. I’m sure it didn’t hurt that he was of Egyptian decent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark silently looks off into the distance, still on the p with Vinny.

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mark? (beat) Can we sell now? The fund’1l make almost a billion dollars... You'll clear 200 mill Mark.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You know once we sell we’re just like all the rest...

dialogues.speaker: VINNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No we're not Mark... We didn’t prey on people's dreams of owning a home... They did. And now we can kick em in the teeth.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: A billion dollars...

dialogues.speaker: VINNY
dialogues.text: That's right. But we’ve got to sell or it could be zero. It’s now or never. It really is. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Okay... Sell it all. The Big Short  BUFF REVISED, MAY 11, 2015 127. MUSIC: ORCHESTRAL THEME. And then over black... “When the dust settled from the collapse 5 trillion dolla in pension money, real estate value, 401k, savings, and b had disappeared. 8 million people lost their jobs, six million lost their homes. And that was just in the USA.” “Charlie Geller and Jamie Shipley attempted to sue the ratings agencies but were laughed out of all law offices. Jamie still runs Brownfield with Ben Rickert but Charlie New York to live in Charlotte and start a family. He did go on Lithium.” “Cynthia says Mark Baum actually became gracious after th collapse and never said “I told you so” to anyone. But he give large sums of his money to a charity that helps peop escape from cults. Danny, Vinny and Porter all still run fund together and are as terrified as ever.” “Michael Burry contacted the government several times to if anyone wanted to interview him to find out how he knew system would collapse years before anyone else. No one ev returned his calls. But he was audited four times and questioned by the FBI. The small investing he still does all focused on one commodity: water.” After a beat... “In 2015 several large banks began selling billions in something called a “bespoke tranche opportunity.” Which according to the Wall Street Journal is just another name a CDO.” END.
